chapter: Resource Acquisition and Transport in Vascular Plants

questions.question: The cohesion-tension theory explains the ascent of xylem sap in plants. According to this theory, the primary driving force for long-distance water transport is:
options: Active pumping by living xylem parenchyma cells that consume ATP to push water upward
Root pressure generated by osmotic uptake of water, which is sufficient to push water to the top of all trees
Capillary action alone, driven by the narrow diameter of xylem vessels

Transpiration-driven tension — evaporation of water from leaf mesophyll cell walls into substomatal air spaces creates a negative water potential (tension) that is transmitted through continuous water columns in the xylem via hydrogen bonds (cohesion) between water molecules and adhesion to xylem walls, pulling water upward from the roots
questions.explanation: The cohesion-tension theory (proposed by Dixon and Joly, 1895) is the accepted mechanism for long-distance water transport: (1) Transpiration pull — water evaporates from the wet cell wall surfaces of mesophyll cells into the substomatal air spaces, then exits through open stomata. This evaporation lowers the water potential at the leaf cell wall surfaces, creating a very negative water potential (as low as -3 MPa in some species). This tension (negative pressure) is transmitted into the leaf xylem. (2) Cohesion — water molecules are held together by hydrogen bonds, giving liquid water remarkable tensile strength. The cohesive forces between water molecules allow the water column in the xylem to be pulled upward as a continuous chain without breaking, even under significant tension. The tensile strength of water in narrow xylem conduits exceeds -30 MPa. (3) Adhesion — water molecules also adhere to the hydrophilic (lignified but wettable) walls of xylem vessels and tracheids. This adhesion helps maintain continuous water columns and contributes to the continuity of the transpiration stream. (4) Continuous pathway — from soil to atmosphere, there is a continuous water pathway: soil water → root epidermis → cortex → endodermis (symplastic crossing) → xylem → stem xylem → leaf xylem → mesophyll cell walls → evaporation. Water moves passively along this entire pathway, following the water potential gradient. (5) Why other options fail — there is no active pumping in xylem (A — xylem conducting cells are dead). Root pressure (B) exists but is insufficient to move water more than a few meters and cannot explain sap rise in tall trees. Capillary action (C) contributes negligibly — it can only raise water about 0.5 m in the narrowest xylem vessels.

questions.question: Water potential (Ψw) is a quantitative measure used to predict the direction of water movement. It is defined as:
options: The total volume of water a cell can hold
The rate of transpiration per unit leaf area
The concentration of all dissolved sugars in the phloem sap

The free energy of water per unit volume relative to pure water at atmospheric pressure — Ψw = Ψs + Ψp, where Ψs (solute potential/osmotic potential) is always negative (solutes lower free energy) and Ψp (pressure potential/turgor) is typically positive in turgid cells; water moves spontaneously from regions of higher (less negative) to lower (more negative) water potential
questions.explanation: Water potential is the central concept in plant water relations and is essential for predicting water movement: (1) Definition — water potential (Ψw) is defined as the chemical potential (free energy) of water per unit volume (or mole), expressed relative to pure water at atmospheric pressure and the same temperature. Units are pressure units (megapascals, MPa). Pure water at atmospheric pressure has Ψw = 0 MPa by convention. (2) Components — Ψw = Ψs + Ψp (in cells; gravity component Ψg is added for tall trees). (a) Solute potential (Ψs, also called osmotic potential, Ψπ): always negative. Dissolved solutes reduce the free energy of water by reducing the mole fraction of water. More concentrated solutions have more negative Ψs. Calculated from the van't Hoff equation: Ψs = -iMRT (where i = ionization constant, M = molarity, R = gas constant, T = temperature in Kelvin). (b) Pressure potential (Ψp): can be positive (turgor pressure in cells), zero, or negative (tension in xylem). In a turgid cell, positive turgor pressure pushes against the cell wall and raises Ψw. In xylem under transpirational tension, Ψp is negative, lowering Ψw significantly. (3) Water movement — water moves spontaneously (passively) from higher Ψw to lower Ψw. This principle governs all water movement in plants: soil → root → stem → leaf → atmosphere. The atmosphere typically has the most negative Ψw (-40 to -100 MPa), creating the driving force for the transpiration stream. (4) At equilibrium — when Ψw is equal across a membrane, net water movement ceases. In a fully turgid cell at equilibrium with pure water: Ψs + Ψp = 0 (Ψp = -Ψs). (5) Plasmolysis — when external Ψw is lower than cell Ψw, water leaves the cell. At incipient plasmolysis, Ψp = 0 and Ψw = Ψs. Volume (A), transpiration rate (B), and sugar concentration (C) do not define water potential.

questions.question: A researcher measures the water potential of soil (Ψ = -0.3 MPa), root xylem (Ψ = -0.6 MPa), leaf xylem (Ψ = -1.2 MPa), and leaf mesophyll cell walls (Ψ = -1.8 MPa). The relative humidity of the atmosphere corresponds to Ψ = -95 MPa. Based on these measurements, which statement is correct?
options: Water will move from the leaf to the soil because leaf Ψ is more negative
Water will move from the atmosphere into the leaf because atmospheric Ψ is most negative
Water cannot move in this system because the gradient is too steep

Water moves spontaneously along the entire soil-plant-atmosphere continuum (SPAC) from soil to atmosphere, following the gradient of decreasing water potential — the enormous drop in Ψw between the leaf mesophyll (-1.8 MPa) and the atmosphere (-95 MPa) at the stomatal pore provides the primary driving force for transpiration, which pulls the entire water column upward
questions.explanation: This question illustrates the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum (SPAC) concept: (1) Water potential gradient — the data shows a continuous decrease in Ψw: soil (-0.3) → root xylem (-0.6) → leaf xylem (-1.2) → mesophyll walls (-1.8) → atmosphere (-95 MPa). Since water moves from higher (less negative) to lower (more negative) Ψw, water flows spontaneously from soil through the plant to the atmosphere. (2) Biggest drop — the enormous difference between mesophyll cell walls (-1.8 MPa) and atmosphere (-95 MPa) represents the largest Ψw gradient in the system. This transition occurs at the leaf surface, where liquid water evaporates into the substomatal air space. The huge driving force at this interface is what makes transpiration so powerful. (3) Calculating atmospheric Ψw — atmospheric water potential depends on relative humidity: Ψw = (RT/Vw) × ln(RH/100), where R = gas constant, T = temperature (K), Vw = partial molar volume of water. At 50% RH and 25°C, Ψw ≈ -95 MPa. Even at 99% RH, atmospheric Ψw ≈ -1.4 MPa. (4) Continuity requirement — for the cohesion-tension mechanism to work, the water column must be continuous from root to leaf. Any break (cavitation/embolism) disrupts tension transmission. Plants have mechanisms to avoid and repair cavitation. (5) Passive process — the entire movement of water through the plant is passive (no ATP required). The energy comes from the sun (which drives evaporation at leaf surfaces, lowering the atmospheric humidity). This makes transpiration essentially solar-powered. Water moves from HIGH to LOW Ψw, not the reverse (A), the atmosphere provides the pull not the push (B), and the gradient is the mechanism, not a barrier (C).

questions.question: Cavitation (embolism) in xylem vessels occurs when the water column breaks under excessive tension, forming air bubbles. Which adaptation helps prevent the spread of embolism from one vessel element to adjacent vessels?
options: Perforation plates at vessel end walls that freely connect adjacent elements
Large-diameter vessels that resist cavitation through greater volume

Pit membranes — the thin, porous primary wall material spanning bordered pits between adjacent vessels acts as a safety valve; when one vessel embolizes, air is prevented from spreading to functional neighboring vessels because the surface tension of water in the tiny pores of the pit membrane resists air entry (air-seeding), effectively isolating the embolized vessel
Absence of all lateral connections between xylem vessels
questions.explanation: Cavitation management is critical for maintaining continuous water transport: (1) Cavitation mechanism — when xylem tension exceeds a critical threshold, dissolved gases come out of solution or air is pulled through pit membranes from an adjacent air-filled space, creating a gas bubble that rapidly expands and blocks the vessel (embolism). Cavitation is more likely under drought stress (more negative Ψp in xylem) and freeze-thaw cycles (dissolved gases form bubbles when ice forms). (2) Pit membrane function — bordered pits connect adjacent vessels and vessel-to-tracheid connections. Each pit has a pit membrane — a modified primary wall (middle lamella + primary wall material) with nano-scale pores (typically 5-20 nm in angiosperm pit membranes, though some species have larger pores). When one vessel embolizes, the air-water meniscus at the pit membrane pores resists air entry into the adjacent functional vessel. Air cannot be 'seeded' through the pit membrane as long as the capillary pressure holding the meniscus in the pore exceeds the xylem tension. (3) Air-seeding threshold — the pressure difference required to force air through a pit membrane pore is given by ΔP = 4T cosθ / D (where T = surface tension of water, θ = contact angle, D = pore diameter). Smaller pores have higher air-seeding thresholds, providing greater safety. This is why pit membrane pore size is a critical determinant of a species' vulnerability to drought-induced embolism. (4) Safety vs. efficiency trade-off — smaller pit membrane pores provide greater cavitation resistance (safety) but also increase hydraulic resistance (reducing flow efficiency). This is the well-known safety-efficiency trade-off in xylem hydraulics. (5) Perforation plates (A) connect vessel elements within the SAME vessel (providing efficiency) but don't prevent embolism spread between vessels. Larger vessels (B) are actually MORE vulnerable to cavitation. Complete isolation (D) would eliminate all lateral transport between vessels.

questions.question: The pressure-flow (Munch) hypothesis explains phloem translocation. According to this model, the movement of phloem sap from source to sink is driven by:
options: Cytoplasmic streaming within individual sieve tube elements

A turgor pressure gradient — active loading of sucrose into sieve tubes at source tissues (leaves) lowers the water potential, causing water to enter by osmosis and creating high turgor pressure; active or passive unloading at sink tissues (roots, fruits, meristems) removes sucrose, raising water potential and reducing turgor; the resulting pressure gradient drives bulk flow of phloem sap from source to sink
Gravity pulling dense sugar solution downward from leaves to roots
Transpirational pull through phloem tubes, identical to xylem transport
questions.explanation: The pressure-flow (mass flow) hypothesis of Ernst Munch (1930) remains the accepted model for phloem translocation: (1) Source end — at source tissues (mature, photosynthetically active leaves), sucrose is loaded into sieve tube elements. This loading can be apoplastic (involving active H+/sucrose cotransport using energy from H+-ATPases — the dominant mechanism in most crop plants) or symplastic (through plasmodesmata, with polymer trapping in species that convert sucrose to raffinose-family oligosaccharides in intermediary cells). The high sucrose concentration in sieve tubes (typically 10-25% w/v, 0.3-0.9 M) creates a very negative solute potential (Ψs), lowering the water potential and causing osmotic water uptake from adjacent xylem. The resulting turgor pressure (Ψp) in source sieve tubes is high (typically 0.7-1.5 MPa). (2) Sink end — at sink tissues (growing roots, developing fruits, storage organs, meristems), sucrose is unloaded from sieve tubes by symplastic unloading (through plasmodesmata) or apoplastic unloading (involving cell wall invertase or sucrose transporters). Sucrose removal raises the sieve tube Ψw at the sink, causing water to leave by osmosis (returning to the xylem). Turgor pressure at the sink end is lower. (3) Pressure gradient — the difference in turgor pressure between source (high Ψp) and sink (low Ψp) drives bulk flow (mass flow) of phloem sap through the sieve tube system. The sap moves through sieve plate pores connecting adjacent sieve tube elements. (4) Velocities — phloem sap velocities range from 0.3-1.5 m/h in most species, much slower than xylem sap (1-45 m/h) but still impressive for a pressure-driven flow system. (5) Evidence — experimental support includes: pressure measurements showing source-sink turgor gradients, radiotracer studies showing bulk movement, and the aphid stylet technique (severing aphid stylets embedded in sieve tubes to collect sap and measure pressure). Cytoplasmic streaming (A) is too slow, gravity (C) cannot explain upward transport to growing shoot tips, and transpirational pull (D) operates in xylem, not phloem.

questions.question: To demonstrate that phloem transport requires metabolic energy (active loading) at the source, a researcher should:
options: Apply a respiratory inhibitor (such as CCCP or cyanide) to the source leaf and measure whether phloem loading and translocation rates decrease — if loading requires ATP-dependent H+/sucrose cotransport, inhibiting respiration should reduce the proton motive force, decrease sucrose loading into sieve tubes, lower sieve tube turgor, and reduce translocation velocity
Cut the stem and observe whether xylem sap continues to flow
Measure leaf temperature during photosynthesis only
Remove all roots and observe whether leaves continue to photosynthesize
questions.explanation: This experiment directly tests the ATP dependence of phloem loading: (1) The apoplastic loading mechanism — in most crop plants and many other species, sucrose is loaded into the sieve element-companion cell (SE-CC) complex from the leaf apoplast via a two-step energy-dependent process: (a) H+-ATPases on the companion cell plasma membrane pump protons (H+) out of the cell, creating a proton motive force (electrochemical gradient). (b) H+/sucrose cotransporters (SUT1/SUC2 family) use the proton motive force to co-transport sucrose and H+ into the SE-CC complex against the sucrose concentration gradient. (2) Experimental design — applying metabolic inhibitors tests ATP dependence: (a) CCCP (carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone) — uncouples oxidative phosphorylation by dissipating the mitochondrial proton gradient, preventing ATP synthesis. (b) Cyanide — inhibits cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) of the electron transport chain. (c) DCCD — inhibits the H+-ATPase directly. If applied to the source leaf (via petiole feeding or local application), these inhibitors should: collapse the proton motive force, halt active sucrose loading, reduce sieve tube sucrose concentration, reduce turgor pressure at the source, and decrease translocation rate. (3) Expected results — translocation velocity (measured by radiotracer movement, fluorescent dye, or MRI) should decrease markedly. Sieve tube sucrose concentration (measured by aphid stylet exudate) should decline. (4) Controls — heat-killed tissue (negative control for all transport), untreated tissue (positive control), and application to sink tissue only (should not affect source loading, confirming site-specific requirement). (5) Why other options fail — xylem sap flow (B) tests xylem, not phloem; leaf temperature (C) is irrelevant to loading; root removal (D) does not test energy dependence of loading specifically.

questions.question: Guard cells regulate stomatal aperture. When guard cells accumulate K+ ions and organic anions (malate), what happens to the stomatal pore?
options: The pore closes because increased solute concentration dehydrates guard cells
The pore remains unchanged because K+ has no osmotic effect

The pore opens — K+ and malate accumulation lowers the solute potential (Ψs) of guard cells, causing water to enter by osmosis, increasing turgor pressure, and making the guard cells swell; because of the radial orientation of cellulose microfibrils in guard cell walls, increased turgor causes guard cells to bow outward, opening the pore between them
The pore opens only if the surrounding epidermal cells also accumulate K+
questions.explanation: Stomatal opening is driven by osmotic swelling of guard cells, which is one of the most important physiological processes in plant biology: (1) Ion accumulation — stomatal opening is initiated by blue light-activated H+-ATPases on the guard cell plasma membrane that pump H+ out of the cell, hyperpolarizing the membrane. This drives K+ influx through voltage-gated inward K+ channels (KAT1/KAT2 in Arabidopsis). Cl- and NO3- also enter through anion channels. Additionally, starch in guard cell chloroplasts is converted to malate (organic anion) by the enzyme PEP carboxylase. (2) Osmotic effect — the accumulated K+ (100-300 mM), Cl-, and malate dramatically lower the solute potential (Ψs) of guard cells, from about -0.5 MPa (closed) to about -2.5 MPa (open). This lowers the water potential (Ψw), causing water to enter by osmosis from surrounding subsidiary and epidermal cells. (3) Volume increase — water entry increases guard cell volume by 40-100%, raising turgor pressure (Ψp) from about 0.5 MPa (closed) to about 3-5 MPa (open). (4) Cellulose microfibril orientation — the key to understanding why swelling opens the pore rather than simply expanding the cell in all directions: cellulose microfibrils in guard cell walls are oriented radially (perpendicular to the pore, like hoops around a barrel). This orientation resists circumferential expansion but allows longitudinal expansion. As turgor increases, the guard cells elongate along their length and bow outward, pulling the inner walls apart and opening the pore. (5) Closing — stomatal closure involves the reverse: ABA signaling triggers anion efflux through SLAC1/SLAH3 channels, depolarizing the membrane, which opens outward K+ channels (GORK) for K+ efflux. Loss of solutes raises Ψw, water exits, turgor drops, and the pore closes. Dehydration does not occur from ion accumulation (A), K+ absolutely has an osmotic effect (B), and surrounding epidermal cells are not required to accumulate K+ (D).

questions.question: Aquaporins play a critical role in plant water transport. These proteins are:
options: Ion channels specific for potassium transport across membranes
ATP-driven water pumps that actively move water against its concentration gradient
Enzymes that hydrolyze water molecules for photosynthesis

Integral membrane proteins that form selective water channels — they are tetrameric complexes in which each monomer contains a central pore lined by hydrophilic residues that allow single-file passage of water molecules while excluding protons and ions; aquaporins are gated (regulated) by phosphorylation, pH, and divalent cations, allowing cells to rapidly adjust membrane water permeability
questions.explanation: Aquaporins are among the most important membrane proteins in plant biology: (1) Discovery — Peter Agre received the 2003 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for discovering aquaporin water channels (initially in human red blood cells, AQP1). Plants have the largest aquaporin gene families of any organisms — Arabidopsis has 35 aquaporin genes, maize has 36+. (2) Structure — each aquaporin monomer has six transmembrane alpha-helices with two half-helices (loops B and E) that dip into the membrane from opposite sides and meet in the center, forming the water-selective pore. The conserved NPA (asparagine-proline-alanine) motifs at the tips of these half-helices are critical for water selectivity. Four monomers assemble into a tetramer in the membrane. (3) Water selectivity — the pore allows single-file passage of water molecules (~3 billion molecules per second per channel) while EXCLUDING protons (H3O+). Proton exclusion is achieved by electrostatic repulsion at the NPA region and by disrupting the hydrogen-bond relay that would otherwise allow proton hopping through a water wire. This is critical because proton leakage would dissipate the transmembrane proton gradient. (4) Plant aquaporin families — (a) PIPs (Plasma membrane Intrinsic Proteins): in the plasma membrane, major regulators of transcellular water flow. (b) TIPs (Tonoplast Intrinsic Proteins): in the vacuolar membrane, regulate vacuolar water movement. (c) NIPs (Nodulin-26-like Intrinsic Proteins): transport water and some solutes (glycerol, silicic acid, arsenite). (d) SIPs (Small basic Intrinsic Proteins): ER-localized. (5) Regulation (gating) — aquaporin activity is regulated by: phosphorylation (promotes opening), dephosphorylation (promotes closing), cytoplasmic pH (acidification closes many aquaporins — important during flooding/anoxia), divalent cations (Ca2+ inhibits), and drought-induced gene expression changes. They are not ion channels (A), ATP pumps (B), or hydrolytic enzymes (C).

questions.question:
Match the following mineral nutrient transport mechanisms in roots with their descriptions:
(P) Mass flow in the apoplast
(Q) Symplastic transport via plasmodesmata
(R) Active transport across the endodermis
(S) Mycorrhizal hyphal delivery

1. Ions move through continuous cytoplasmic connections between cells without crossing any membranes
2. Water and dissolved ions move through cell walls and intercellular spaces, driven by transpirational bulk flow
3. Ions must cross the plasma membrane of endodermal cells because the Casparian strip blocks the apoplastic pathway
4. Fungal hyphae absorb mineral nutrients from soil beyond the root depletion zone and transport them to the root cortex through the fungal network
questions.explanation: Mineral nutrient acquisition involves multiple transport pathways from soil to the vascular cylinder: (1) Mass flow in the apoplast (P-2) — as transpiration drives water uptake, dissolved mineral ions are carried along with water through the apoplast (cell walls and intercellular spaces) of the root cortex. This is a passive, non-selective process driven by the transpirational water flow. The apoplastic pathway is rapid but non-selective — any ion dissolved in the soil solution can be carried along. This pathway is blocked at the endodermis by the Casparian strip. (2) Symplastic transport (Q-1) — ions that enter the cytoplasm of root epidermal cells (through membrane transporters) can move from cell to cell through plasmodesmata without crossing additional membranes. Plasmodesmata provide cytoplasmic continuity between adjacent cells, creating a symplastic domain. This pathway allows regulated, selective transport because the initial membrane crossing at the root surface involves specific transport proteins. (3) Active transport at endodermis (R-3) — the Casparian strip in the endodermis blocks all apoplastic movement of ions from cortex to stele. Therefore, all ions must cross the plasma membrane of an endodermal cell to enter the stele. This requires membrane transport proteins: H+-ATPases create the proton motive force, and various secondary active transporters (H+/cation cotransporters, anion channels) move specific ions across the membrane. This selective checkpoint ensures that only ions with appropriate transporters can enter the vascular system. (4) Mycorrhizal delivery (S-4) — mycorrhizal fungi (both ectomycorrhizal and arbuscular mycorrhizal) extend their hyphae far beyond the root nutrient depletion zone (up to 10+ cm from the root surface). Hyphae absorb nutrients (especially phosphorus, but also nitrogen, zinc, copper) from the bulk soil and transport them through the fungal mycelial network to the root cortex, where nutrients are exchanged at the mycorrhizal interface.

questions.question: Guttation — the exudation of liquid water droplets from leaf margins — occurs when:
options: Transpiration rate is very high and xylem pressure is extremely negative
Guard cells actively secrete excess water through stomata during midday

Root pressure forces xylem sap out through hydathodes when transpiration is low — this typically occurs at night or early morning when high humidity and low temperatures minimize transpiration, but the roots continue actively absorbing minerals, generating positive xylem pressure that pushes water out through hydathodes (specialized pore structures) at leaf margins or tips
Phloem sap leaks through damaged bark and flows to leaf edges
questions.explanation: Guttation is a visible manifestation of root pressure: (1) Root pressure — root cells actively transport mineral ions (K+, NO3-, etc.) into the xylem, lowering the xylem sap water potential. This causes osmotic uptake of water from the soil into the xylem, generating positive pressure (root pressure, typically 0.1-0.5 MPa). Root pressure can only build when transpiration is low or absent. (2) Conditions for guttation — guttation occurs when: (a) the soil is moist (water is available for absorption), (b) transpiration is minimal (humid air, cool temperatures, darkness — stomata closed), and (c) root metabolic activity continues (roots keep pumping ions). These conditions typically occur at night or early morning. (3) Hydathodes — the liquid water exits through hydathodes, which are specialized structures located at leaf margins, tips, or serrations. A hydathode consists of: (a) a water pore (a permanently open modified stoma that does not regulate its aperture), (b) epithem tissue (loose, colorless parenchyma with large intercellular spaces), and (c) a terminal tracheid or small vein ending that connects to the xylem. (4) Guttation fluid — the exuded liquid is dilute xylem sap containing some dissolved minerals and organic compounds. It is distinct from dew (which condenses from the atmosphere onto cold leaf surfaces). (5) Significance — guttation demonstrates that roots can generate positive xylem pressure through active mineral pumping. However, root pressure is insufficient for long-distance water transport in most plants (it can push water only a few meters) and is insignificant compared to transpiration pull in driving the transpiration stream during the day. High transpiration (A), guard cell secretion (B), and phloem leakage (D) do not cause guttation.

questions.question: The stomatal response to drought involves the hormone ABA (abscisic acid). ABA promotes stomatal closure through which signaling pathway?
options: ABA directly blocks aquaporins in guard cells, preventing water entry
ABA activates cellulose synthase to thicken guard cell walls
ABA stimulates K+ influx into guard cells, causing excessive turgor

ABA binds to the PYR/PYL/RCAR receptor, which inhibits PP2C phosphatases — this releases SnRK2 kinases from inhibition, allowing SnRK2 to phosphorylate and activate SLAC1 anion channels (causing Cl- and malate efflux) and NADPH oxidases (producing ROS), while simultaneously inhibiting KAT1 inward K+ channels; the resulting solute loss from guard cells leads to water efflux, turgor loss, and stomatal closure
questions.explanation: The ABA signaling pathway for stomatal closure is one of the best-characterized plant signaling cascades: (1) ABA perception — ABA binds to intracellular receptors of the PYR/PYL/RCAR family (14 members in Arabidopsis). The ABA-receptor complex then binds to and inhibits type 2C protein phosphatases (PP2Cs: ABI1, ABI2, HAB1, PP2CA). In the absence of ABA, PP2Cs are active and dephosphorylate (inactivate) SnRK2 kinases. (2) SnRK2 activation — when PP2Cs are inhibited by ABA-receptor complexes, SnRK2 kinases (particularly SnRK2.6/OST1 in guard cells) undergo autophosphorylation and become active. Active SnRK2 kinases phosphorylate multiple downstream targets. (3) Anion channel activation — SnRK2 directly phosphorylates and activates SLAC1 (SLOW ANION CHANNEL-ASSOCIATED 1), the main S-type anion channel in guard cells. Activated SLAC1 allows efflux of Cl- and malate, depolarizing the guard cell membrane. Additionally, R-type anion channels (QUAC1/ALMT12) are also activated. (4) K+ channel regulation — membrane depolarization (from anion efflux) activates GORK (outward-rectifying K+ channel), causing K+ efflux. Simultaneously, SnRK2 phosphorylates and inhibits KAT1 (inward K+ channel), preventing K+ influx. Net result: massive K+, Cl-, and malate efflux. (5) ROS and Ca2+ signaling — SnRK2 also activates NADPH oxidase (RBOHD/RBOHF), producing reactive oxygen species (superoxide → H2O2) in the apoplast. ROS activate Ca2+ channels, increasing cytosolic [Ca2+], which further promotes anion channel activity and inhibits H+-ATPases. (6) Turgor loss — the net loss of osmotically active solutes raises guard cell Ψw, causing water efflux, turgor loss, and stomatal closure. ABA does not directly block aquaporins (A), activate cellulose synthase (B), or stimulate K+ influx (C).

questions.question: A researcher applies radioactive 14C-sucrose to a mature source leaf and tracks its movement through the plant. After 1 hour, autoradiography shows the label has moved to developing fruits (above the labeled leaf) and to root tips (below). This bidirectional movement from a single source demonstrates:
options: That xylem can transport sugars both upward and downward simultaneously
That sucrose diffuses randomly through the apoplast in all directions
That individual sieve tubes can transport in both directions at once

That phloem translocation follows source-to-sink gradients — a single source leaf can supply multiple sinks in different directions simultaneously because different sieve tube elements within the phloem connect to different sink tissues; the direction of flow in each sieve tube is determined by the local turgor pressure gradient between that tube's source and sink connections
questions.explanation: Bidirectional phloem transport from a single source is an important concept: (1) Multiple sinks — a mature leaf (source) simultaneously supplies photosynthate to multiple sink organs: shoot apical meristems, developing leaves, fruits/seeds (above), and root tips, storage organs (below). Each sink draws on the source through different phloem pathways. (2) Different sieve tubes — bidirectional movement does NOT mean a single sieve tube transports in both directions simultaneously (C is wrong). Within the phloem of a vascular bundle, different sieve tube elements may be connected to different sink pathways. Some tubes carry sap upward (to shoot sinks), while adjacent tubes carry sap downward (to root sinks). The direction in each tube is determined by the pressure gradient: sap flows from the high-pressure source end to the low-pressure sink end. (3) Source-sink relationships — the allocation of photosynthate among competing sinks depends on: (a) sink strength (ability to attract and utilize assimilates — determined by size and metabolic activity), (b) proximity (nearby sinks tend to receive more), and (c) vascular connections (phloem architecture determines which sinks are accessible from which sources). (4) Experimental evidence — radiotracer experiments with 14C-sucrose and more modern approaches (11C-PET imaging, MRI velocimetry) have confirmed simultaneous transport to multiple sinks. Aphid stylet measurements at different positions confirm different flow velocities and directions in different sieve tubes. (5) Not xylem (A) — xylem transports water, not sucrose, and flow is unidirectional (upward). Not random diffusion (B) — phloem transport is a directed bulk flow process, not diffusion (which would be far too slow). Not bidirectional within one tube (C) — each sieve tube element carries flow in one direction at any given time.

questions.question: Root hairs dramatically increase the absorptive surface area of roots. Each root hair is:
options: A tubular extension of a single epidermal cell (trichoblast) — root hairs are not separate cells but rather elongated protrusions of the outer wall of individual epidermal cells, typically 80-1500 micrometers long and 5-17 micrometers in diameter; they can increase root surface area by 2-10 fold and are critical for absorbing water and nutrients, especially phosphorus, from the soil
A multicellular structure composed of several fused epidermal cells
A specialized lateral root that grows horizontally through the soil
A fungal hypha that has been incorporated into the root surface
questions.explanation: Root hairs are among the most important structures for plant nutrient acquisition: (1) Cellular nature — each root hair is a single tubular extension of one root epidermal cell. The cell that produces a root hair is called a trichoblast, while epidermal cells that do not produce root hairs are called atrichoblasts. The root hair is NOT a separate cell — it is a protrusion of the trichoblast, sharing the same cytoplasm, nucleus, and vacuole. (2) Dimensions — root hairs are typically 80-1500 micrometers (0.08-1.5 mm) long and 5-17 micrometers in diameter. They are invisible to the naked eye individually but collectively give the root a fuzzy appearance (the root hair zone). (3) Surface area increase — root hairs dramatically increase the root surface area available for absorption. A single rye (Secale cereale) plant was estimated to have approximately 14 billion root hairs with a combined surface area of about 400 m2, compared to about 200 m2 for the root surface without hairs. This represents a 2-10 fold increase depending on species and conditions. (4) Nutrient absorption — root hairs are especially important for absorbing immobile nutrients like phosphorus (Pi). Pi is rapidly depleted from the rhizosphere (the soil zone immediately around the root), creating a depletion zone. Root hairs extend beyond this zone to access undepleted soil. Phosphorus-deficient plants typically produce longer and more numerous root hairs. (5) Location — root hairs form in the maturation zone of the root, behind the elongation zone. They are short-lived (days to weeks) and are continuously replaced by new root hairs as the root tip grows forward. Root hairs on older parts of the root die and slough off. They are not multicellular (B), not lateral roots (C), and not fungal hyphae (D), though they can be functionally complemented by mycorrhizal hyphae.

questions.question: Transpiration accounts for over 95% of water absorbed by most plants. While it drives the essential xylem water transport, excessive transpiration under drought conditions is harmful. Which of the following is NOT a mechanism plants use to reduce transpirational water loss?
options: Stomatal closure mediated by ABA signaling during water stress
Thick waxy cuticle on leaf surfaces reducing cuticular transpiration
Leaf rolling or wilting that reduces the exposed surface area

Increasing stomatal density on the adaxial leaf surface to maximize water loss — in reality, drought-adapted plants reduce stomatal density, and many xerophytes have sunken stomata enclosed in crypts with trichomes to trap humid air and reduce the vapor pressure gradient driving transpiration
questions.explanation: Plants have evolved numerous adaptations to manage transpirational water loss: (1) Stomatal closure (A — IS a mechanism) — the most rapid and important short-term response. ABA produced in response to soil drying activates the PYR/PYL → PP2C → SnRK2 → SLAC1 pathway, causing guard cell solute loss and stomatal closure within minutes. This can reduce transpiration by >90%. (2) Thick cuticle (B — IS a mechanism) — a thick, wax-rich cuticle reduces cuticular transpiration (water loss through the leaf surface independent of stomata). Cuticular transpiration typically accounts for 5-10% of total transpiration in mesophytes but can be reduced to 1-2% in xerophytes with heavy cuticle deposition. (3) Leaf rolling/wilting (C — IS a mechanism) — some grasses (e.g., corn, rice) have bulliform cells in the adaxial epidermis that lose turgor during drought, causing the leaf to roll inward, reducing the exposed surface area and trapping humid air inside the rolled leaf. Wilting (loss of turgor in mesophyll and epidermal cells) also reduces exposed area. (4) Increasing adaxial stomatal density (D — NOT a mechanism, correct answer) — drought-adapted plants actually REDUCE stomatal density (fewer stomata per unit area) and often have stomata only on the abaxial surface (hypostomatic leaves). Xerophytes commonly have sunken stomata (recessed in pits below the leaf surface), stomatal crypts (chambers containing stomata, often filled with trichomes), and dense trichome coverage to trap a boundary layer of humid air. All of these REDUCE transpiration. Increasing stomatal density would increase water loss and is the opposite of drought adaptation. (5) Additional mechanisms — CAM photosynthesis (opening stomata only at night), leaf shedding (deciduous drought response), deep root systems, succulent water storage tissues, and osmotic adjustment (accumulating compatible solutes to maintain turgor).

questions.question: A researcher wants to measure the actual tension (negative pressure) in functioning xylem vessels of a transpiring plant. The best technique is:
options: Measuring turgor pressure of surrounding parenchyma cells with a pressure probe
Weighing the plant before and after a period of transpiration

Using a Scholander pressure bomb (pressure chamber) — a cut shoot or leaf is enclosed in a sealed chamber with the cut stem end protruding; gas pressure is applied until xylem sap just reappears at the cut surface; this balancing pressure equals the magnitude of the tension (negative pressure) that existed in the xylem before cutting
Observing bubble formation in cut stem segments under a microscope
questions.explanation: The Scholander pressure bomb (pressure chamber) is the standard tool for measuring xylem water potential and tension in plant tissues: (1) Principle — when a stem or petiole is cut from a transpiring plant, the xylem sap retreats from the cut surface into the tissue because the tension (negative pressure) that was holding the sap in the xylem is released and the sap is pulled back by the still-existing tension in the connected xylem network within the leaf/shoot. (2) Procedure — (a) Cut the shoot/leaf from the plant. (b) Immediately place it in the pressure chamber with only the cut end protruding through a gas-tight seal. (c) Gradually increase the gas pressure (compressed nitrogen) inside the chamber. The applied positive pressure pushes water back toward the cut surface against the matric and osmotic forces that pulled it into the tissue. (d) The 'balance pressure' — the pressure at which xylem sap just reappears at the cut surface — equals the magnitude of the xylem tension (water potential) that existed before cutting. (3) Assumptions — the technique assumes that: (a) xylem sap has negligible solute potential (Ψs ≈ 0), so the measured balance pressure equals -Ψp, (b) no significant water loss occurs between cutting and measurement, and (c) the applied pressure uniformly compresses the tissue. (4) Typical values — midday xylem tensions in well-watered plants: -0.5 to -2.0 MPa. Drought-stressed plants: -2 to -8 MPa or more. Desert species like creosote bush (Larrea tridentata) can sustain tensions below -8 MPa. (5) Alternative methods — the xylem pressure probe (Zimmermann) directly measures xylem pressure by inserting a glass microcapillary into a vessel, but it is technically challenging and limited to superficial vessels. Parenchyma pressure probes (A) measure cell turgor, not xylem tension. Weighing (B) measures transpiration rate, not tension. Observing bubbles (D) indicates cavitation but doesn't quantify tension.

questions.question: Mineral nutrients are classified as macronutrients or micronutrients based on the amount required by plants. Which of the following is a micronutrient (trace element) essential for plant growth?
options: Nitrogen (N), which is a major component of amino acids and nucleic acids
Potassium (K), which is required for osmotic regulation and enzyme activation
Phosphorus (P), which is a component of ATP, nucleic acids, and phospholipids

Molybdenum (Mo) — required in extremely small quantities (typically 0.1-1 ppm in plant tissue) as a cofactor for enzymes including nitrate reductase (which reduces NO3- to NO2- in the nitrogen assimilation pathway) and nitrogenase (in nitrogen-fixing bacteria); Mo deficiency impairs nitrogen metabolism even when nitrogen supply is adequate
questions.explanation: The distinction between macronutrients and micronutrients is fundamental to plant nutrition: (1) Macronutrients — required in large amounts (>0.1% of plant dry weight). Nine macronutrients: C, H, O (from water and CO2), N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S. These form the structural components of organic molecules (C, H, O, N, P, S) or function in high concentrations in physiological processes (K, Ca, Mg). (2) Micronutrients (trace elements) — required in very small amounts (<0.01% or <100 ppm). Eight micronutrients: Fe, Mn, Zn, Cu, B, Mo, Cl, Ni. Despite their tiny concentrations, they are absolutely essential — deficiency of any one causes specific disease symptoms and can be lethal. (3) Molybdenum (Mo) — required in the smallest amount of any mineral nutrient. Key functions: (a) Cofactor for nitrate reductase — the enzyme that catalyzes the first step of nitrate assimilation (NO3- → NO2-). Without Mo, plants cannot reduce nitrate to a usable form, even if nitrate is abundant in the soil. Mo deficiency symptoms mimic nitrogen deficiency. (b) Cofactor for xanthine dehydrogenase and aldehyde oxidase — involved in purine catabolism and ABA biosynthesis. (c) Component of the Mo cofactor (Moco) — a pterin-based cofactor shared by all Mo-dependent enzymes in eukaryotes. (d) Required by nitrogenase in nitrogen-fixing bacteria (Rhizobium in root nodules) — Mo is part of the FeMo-cofactor at the active site of nitrogenase. (4) N (A), K (B), and P (C) are all macronutrients required in much larger quantities (1-5% of dry weight for N and K, 0.2-0.5% for P). They are essential but are not micronutrients.

questions.question: Crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM) is a photosynthetic adaptation that minimizes transpirational water loss. CAM plants accomplish this by:
options: Opening stomata during the day when transpiration is highest to maximize CO2 uptake
Eliminating stomata entirely and absorbing CO2 through the cuticle

Opening stomata only at night when transpiration rates are lower — CO2 fixed at night by PEP carboxylase is stored as malic acid in the vacuole; during the day, stomata close to conserve water, malic acid is decarboxylated to release CO2 for the Calvin cycle, and photosynthesis proceeds using this internally released CO2 behind closed stomata
Using only C4 photosynthesis with mesophyll and bundle sheath cell specialization
questions.explanation: CAM is an elegant temporal separation of CO2 fixation and the Calvin cycle: (1) Nighttime phase — stomata OPEN at night when the air is cooler and relative humidity is higher, dramatically reducing transpirational water loss (compared to daytime opening). CO2 enters through open stomata and is fixed by PEP carboxylase (PEPC) using phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) as the CO2 acceptor, producing oxaloacetate (OAA). OAA is immediately reduced to malate by malate dehydrogenase (MDH). Malate is transported into the large central vacuole, where it is stored as malic acid. The vacuolar pH drops from ~5.5 to ~3.5 as malic acid accumulates, causing the characteristic nighttime acidification. (2) Daytime phase — stomata CLOSE during the day, preventing water loss. Malic acid is released from the vacuole and decarboxylated by NAD(P)-malic enzyme or PEP carboxykinase (depending on species), releasing CO2. This CO2 is refixed by rubisco in the Calvin cycle for sugar production. The closed stomata trap the internally released CO2, raising the internal CO2 concentration around rubisco and suppressing photorespiration. (3) Water use efficiency — CAM plants can have water use efficiency (WUE) 3-6 times higher than C3 plants. A typical CAM plant transpires 50-100 g water per g dry matter, compared to 400-500 g for C3 plants. (4) CAM species — found in over 30 plant families, including Crassulaceae (stonecrops), Cactaceae (cacti), Orchidaceae (many epiphytic orchids), Bromeliaceae (pineapple), Agavaceae (agave), and Euphorbiaceae (some spurges). Most are succulent plants with large vacuoles for acid storage. (5) Facultative CAM — some plants (e.g., Mesembryanthemum crystallinum, ice plant) can switch between C3 and CAM photosynthesis depending on water availability, demonstrating that CAM is a regulated adaptation. Opening stomata during the day (A) is what C3 plants do, eliminating stomata (B) would prevent all gas exchange, and C4 uses spatial separation rather than temporal separation (D).

questions.question: The Casparian strip forces all water and ions entering the stele to pass through the symplast. This has important consequences for ion selectivity. Which membrane transport protein is primarily responsible for loading K+ into the xylem for long-distance transport to the shoot?
options: SKOR (Stelar K+ Outward Rectifier) — an outward-rectifying K+ channel expressed in xylem parenchyma cells of the root stele that releases K+ from the symplast into the xylem apoplast (vessel lumen) for loading into the transpiration stream; SKOR is activated by membrane depolarization and is essential for K+ delivery to the shoot
KAT1, the guard cell inward K+ channel
AKT1, the root epidermal K+ uptake channel
NHX1, the vacuolar Na+/H+ antiporter
questions.explanation: Xylem K+ loading is a critical step in long-distance potassium transport from roots to shoots: (1) The loading problem — after K+ is absorbed by root epidermal cells (via AKT1 and other uptake transporters) and moves through the symplast to the stele, it must be released from the living xylem parenchyma cells INTO the dead, apoplastic xylem vessels (xylem loading). This step requires specific channels/transporters because the plasma membrane is the last membrane barrier. (2) SKOR channel — SKOR (Stelar K+ Outward-Rectifying channel) is the primary K+ channel responsible for xylem K+ loading. Key features: (a) Expression: specifically in root stelar tissues (pericycle and xylem parenchyma), not in the cortex or epidermis. (b) Rectification: outward-rectifying — opens when the membrane depolarizes, allowing K+ to flow OUT of the cell into the xylem apoplast. (c) Knockout phenotype: skor knockout mutants have approximately 50% reduced K+ content in shoots, demonstrating its importance for root-to-shoot K+ translocation. Xylem sap K+ concentration is markedly reduced. (3) AKT1 (C) — is an inward-rectifying K+ channel expressed in root epidermis and cortex. It mediates K+ UPTAKE from the soil into the root symplast. It is upstream of xylem loading. (4) KAT1 (B) — is the guard cell inward K+ channel that mediates K+ uptake during stomatal opening. It is expressed in guard cells, not root stele. (5) NHX1 (D) — is a vacuolar Na+/H+ antiporter involved in Na+ sequestration (salt tolerance) and vacuolar pH regulation, not xylem K+ loading.

questions.question: Phloem sap collected using the aphid stylet technique typically contains 10-25% sucrose (w/v) and much lower concentrations of amino acids. Which amino acid is most abundant in phloem sap and serves as a primary nitrogen transport form?
options: Tryptophan, due to its role as an auxin precursor

Glutamine — with two nitrogen atoms per molecule (one in the alpha-amino group, one in the amide group), glutamine is an efficient nitrogen carrier and is the predominant amino acid in the phloem sap of most plant species, serving as the major form of organic nitrogen transport from source leaves to nitrogen-demanding sink tissues
Proline, because it is the most abundant amino acid in all proteins
Cysteine, because sulfur must be transported in amino acid form
questions.explanation: Nitrogen transport in the phloem is essential for supplying nitrogen to sink tissues: (1) Phloem sap composition — phloem sap is primarily sucrose (10-25% w/v, or 0.3-0.9 M), with amino acids present at much lower concentrations (typically 0.3-3% w/v). Amino acids are the primary organic nitrogen transport forms. Potassium (K+) is the major inorganic cation (50-100 mM). (2) Glutamine dominance — glutamine is the most abundant amino acid in the phloem sap of most plant species, typically accounting for 20-50% of total amino acids. Several factors make glutamine an ideal nitrogen transport molecule: (a) Two nitrogen atoms per molecule — glutamine (C5H10N2O3) has both an alpha-amino group and a gamma-amide group, making it the most efficient amino acid for nitrogen transport (two N per molecule vs. one for most amino acids). (b) High N:C ratio — glutamine has 2N per 5C, compared to asparagine's 2N per 4C (asparagine is also abundant in phloem sap for this reason). (c) Chemical stability — glutamine is relatively stable and soluble. (d) GS/GOGAT cycle — glutamine synthetase (GS) in source leaves assimilates recycled NH4+ (from photorespiration, protein degradation, nitrate reduction) into glutamine, which is then loaded into the phloem. (3) Other transport amino acids — asparagine (also has 2N, abundant in legumes), glutamate, aspartate, and serine are also common phloem amino acids, but glutamine typically dominates. (4) Significance — nitrogen remobilization from senescing leaves (which can recapture 50-80% of leaf nitrogen) is primarily via glutamine transport in the phloem. Tryptophan (A) is present in trace amounts only, proline (C) is an osmolyte not a major transport form, and cysteine (D) is relatively rare in phloem sap.

questions.question: A plant physiologist measures transpiration rate and stomatal conductance throughout the day. Transpiration peaks at midday, then drops sharply even though light intensity remains high. This midday depression of transpiration is most likely caused by:
options: Decreased light intensity from cloud cover
A sudden drop in air temperature reducing evaporative demand

Midday stomatal closure triggered by leaf-to-air vapor pressure deficit (VPD) — as temperature rises and relative humidity drops at midday, VPD increases, causing guard cells to close stomata (partially mediated by ABA) to prevent excessive water loss; this reduces transpiration despite continued high light, representing a trade-off between water conservation and CO2 uptake for photosynthesis
Root pressure pushing water upward so fast that transpiration is no longer needed
questions.explanation: The midday depression of transpiration is a well-documented phenomenon in many plant species: (1) Vapor pressure deficit (VPD) — VPD is the difference between the saturation vapor pressure of air and the actual vapor pressure. At midday, high temperatures increase saturation vapor pressure while relative humidity often drops, creating a large VPD. A large VPD drives rapid transpiration, which can exceed the rate of water supply from roots, leading to declining leaf water potential. (2) Guard cell response — as leaf water potential drops and/or VPD increases, guard cells respond by partially closing stomata. This response involves: (a) Hydraulic signaling — reduced turgor in guard cells due to rapid water loss. (b) ABA signaling — drought-induced ABA synthesis in leaves (ABA is synthesized in mesophyll cells from xanthoxin via NCED enzyme, transported to guard cells). (c) Direct VPD sensing — guard cells may sense humidity directly, with reduced humidity causing passive water loss from guard cells faster than the rate at which osmotic solute accumulation can maintain turgor. (3) Trade-off — midday stomatal closure reduces transpiration but also reduces CO2 uptake, limiting photosynthesis during the period of highest light intensity. This is a classical physiological trade-off between water conservation and carbon gain. Plants in well-watered conditions may show minimal midday depression, while drought-stressed plants show pronounced depression. (4) Afternoon recovery — as temperature drops and VPD decreases in the late afternoon, stomata may partially reopen, leading to a secondary peak in transpiration. (5) Species variation — the extent of midday depression varies among species. Isohydric species (e.g., maize) maintain relatively constant leaf water potential by closing stomata aggressively. Anisohydric species (e.g., sunflower) allow leaf water potential to decline, maintaining stomata more open but risking cavitation. Cloud cover (A), temperature drop (B), and root pressure (D) do not explain the pattern.

questions.question: Nitrogen fixation — the conversion of atmospheric N2 to NH3 — is performed by certain prokaryotes. In the Rhizobium-legume symbiosis, the enzyme nitrogenase is extremely sensitive to oxygen. How do root nodules protect nitrogenase from O2 damage?
options: Nodules lack all living cells, creating a completely anaerobic dead zone
Rhizobium bacteria do not require any oxygen for their metabolism

Leghemoglobin — a plant-produced oxygen-binding protein in nodules that maintains free O2 concentration at extremely low levels (10-30 nM) while still facilitating O2 delivery to Rhizobium bacteroids for their aerobic respiration; the nodule cortex also has an oxygen diffusion barrier that limits O2 entry
Nitrogenase functions optimally at high O2 concentrations and does not need protection
questions.explanation: The oxygen paradox in nitrogen-fixing nodules is solved by leghemoglobin: (1) The paradox — nitrogenase (the enzyme that catalyzes N2 + 8H+ + 8e- + 16ATP → 2NH3 + H2 + 16ADP + 16Pi) is irreversibly inactivated by O2. Even brief exposure to O2 damages the iron-sulfur clusters and FeMo-cofactor of the enzyme. However, the nitrogen-fixing bacteroids (differentiated Rhizobium cells inside nodule cells) require O2 for aerobic respiration to generate the enormous amount of ATP (16 ATP per N2 fixed) needed for nitrogen fixation. (2) Leghemoglobin (Lb) — a hemoglobin-like protein found in root nodule cells. Characteristics: (a) Pink/red color — gives active nodules their characteristic pink interior. Inactive or senescent nodules turn green (degraded Lb). (b) Extremely high O2 affinity — Lb has a much higher O2 affinity than animal hemoglobin. It binds O2 very tightly, maintaining the free dissolved O2 concentration in the nodule cytosol at only 10-30 nM — low enough to protect nitrogenase. (c) O2 delivery — despite the extremely low free O2, Lb-bound O2 (oxyLb) diffuses to bacteroid membranes and releases O2 at a controlled rate to high-affinity terminal oxidases (fixN/fixO cytochrome oxidase) in the bacteroid inner membrane. This allows sufficient O2 delivery for respiration while keeping free O2 critically low. (d) Synthesis — the globin protein is encoded by the plant genome; the heme group synthesis involves contributions from both plant and bacteroid. (3) Oxygen diffusion barrier — the nodule cortex contains a layer of tightly packed cells with few intercellular spaces, creating a physical barrier that limits O2 diffusion into the central infected zone. This barrier is the primary regulator of overall O2 flux into the nodule. (4) Complementary mechanisms — bacteroid respiration rapidly consumes any free O2, acting as an O2 scavenging system. Nodules are not anaerobic dead zones (A), bacteroids need O2 (B), and nitrogenase is O2-sensitive, not O2-tolerant (D).

questions.question: The three pathways for water movement through root tissues to the xylem are the apoplastic, symplastic, and transmembrane pathways. The transmembrane pathway differs from the symplastic pathway in that:
options: The transmembrane pathway uses plasmodesmata to bypass cell walls entirely
The transmembrane pathway involves water moving through the apoplast only, never entering cells
Both pathways are identical and cannot be distinguished experimentally

In the transmembrane pathway, water alternately crosses plasma membranes (entering and exiting cells) and passes through cell walls, requiring water to cross two membranes per cell traversed — in contrast, the symplastic pathway uses plasmodesmata connections so water moves through continuous cytoplasm without crossing membranes after the initial entry
questions.explanation: The three pathways for radial water movement across the root are often confused: (1) Apoplastic pathway — water moves entirely through the cell wall continuum (cell walls + intercellular spaces) without crossing any plasma membrane. This is a passive, non-selective pathway driven by mass flow (transpiration pull). The apoplastic pathway is blocked at the endodermis by the Casparian strip, forcing water into the symplast at this point. (2) Symplastic pathway — water enters the cytoplasm of an outer root cell (crossing one plasma membrane via aquaporins or by osmosis) and then moves from cell to cell through plasmodesmata without crossing any additional membranes. Plasmodesmata provide cytoplasmic continuity between adjacent cells, so the entire symplast is a continuous cytoplasmic compartment connected by these channels. (3) Transmembrane pathway — water moves across the root by alternately: (a) crossing the plasma membrane to enter a cell (via aquaporins), (b) traversing the cytoplasm, (c) crossing the plasma membrane to exit the cell into the cell wall, (d) moving through the cell wall, and (e) crossing the plasma membrane of the next cell. Each cell traversed requires crossing two membranes (entry + exit). (4) Key difference — in the symplastic pathway, water enters the symplast once and then moves through plasmodesmata (no more membrane crossings). In the transmembrane pathway, water crosses membranes repeatedly at each cell. The transmembrane pathway is therefore more influenced by aquaporin abundance and activity than the symplastic pathway. (5) In practice — the three pathways operate simultaneously, and their relative contributions vary with species, tissue age, water availability, and aquaporin regulation. At the endodermis, only the symplastic and transmembrane pathways are available (apoplast is blocked). Plasmodesmata (A) are part of the symplastic pathway; the transmembrane pathway does enter cells (B); and the pathways are experimentally distinguishable (C) using aquaporin inhibitors (HgCl2) and plasmodesmata modulators.

questions.question: To test the Munch pressure-flow hypothesis directly, a researcher needs to demonstrate that phloem sap moves by bulk flow driven by a turgor pressure gradient. The most informative approach would be to:
options: Measure sugar concentration in leaves only
Observe phloem anatomy in cross-sections without any physiological measurements

Use aphid stylets to simultaneously measure sieve tube turgor pressure at multiple points along the transport pathway — if the pressure-flow hypothesis is correct, turgor pressure should be higher at source regions (where sucrose is loaded) and progressively lower toward sink regions (where sucrose is unloaded), creating a continuous pressure gradient that drives bulk flow
Apply auxin to the phloem to stimulate faster sugar transport
questions.explanation: Testing the Munch hypothesis requires demonstrating a turgor pressure gradient in sieve tubes: (1) The key prediction — the pressure-flow hypothesis predicts that sieve tube turgor pressure is highest at source tissues (due to osmotic water uptake driven by high sucrose concentration) and lowest at sink tissues (due to sucrose removal and water efflux). The pressure gradient between source and sink drives bulk flow of phloem sap. (2) Aphid stylet technique — aphids (particularly the green peach aphid, Myzus persicae) insert their stylets (needle-like mouthparts) into individual sieve tube elements with remarkable precision. When the aphid is anesthetized and its body severed from the stylet, phloem sap exudes from the cut stylet under positive pressure. This exudate can be collected for composition analysis. The stylet can also be connected to a pressure transducer to measure sieve tube turgor directly. (3) Multiple-point measurements — by positioning aphids at different locations along the transport pathway (near source leaves vs. near sink tissues) and measuring turgor at each point, researchers can map the pressure gradient. If measurements show: (a) High turgor near sources and (b) progressively lower turgor toward sinks, with (c) a continuous gradient, this directly supports the pressure-flow mechanism. (4) Experimental results — such experiments have indeed demonstrated source-to-sink turgor gradients, supporting Munch's hypothesis. Typical sieve tube turgor pressures: 0.6-3.0 MPa at sources, 0.3-1.0 MPa at sinks, with the gradient being sufficient to account for observed translocation velocities given sieve tube dimensions and resistance. (5) Complementary evidence — radioisotope velocity measurements, analysis of sieve tube dimensions and resistance calculations, and mathematical modeling all support the pressure-flow mechanism. Sugar concentration measurement alone (A), anatomy alone (B), and auxin application (D) do not directly test the pressure gradient prediction.

questions.question: Halophytes are plants adapted to high-salinity environments. Which of the following is NOT a mechanism halophytes use to tolerate salt stress?
options: Compartmentalizing Na+ in vacuoles using NHX-type Na+/H+ antiporters to prevent cytoplasmic toxicity
Accumulating compatible solutes (glycine betaine, proline) in the cytoplasm to balance vacuolar osmotic potential without enzyme inhibition
Excreting salt through specialized salt glands or bladder cells on leaf surfaces

Actively pumping NaCl into the xylem for rapid transport to and accumulation in young, growing leaves — in reality, salt-tolerant plants restrict Na+ loading into the xylem (via HKT1 transporters that retrieve Na+ from the xylem sap) and preferentially accumulate salt in older, expendable leaves
questions.explanation: Halophyte salt tolerance involves multiple complementary mechanisms: (1) Vacuolar compartmentalization (A — IS a mechanism) — Na+ is sequestered in the vacuole by tonoplast NHX1 (Na+/H+ antiporter), powered by the vacuolar H+-ATPase and H+-PPase. This prevents toxic Na+ accumulation in the cytoplasm (where Na+ concentrations above 100 mM inhibit enzymes). The vacuolar Na+ also serves as an osmoticum, helping maintain cell turgor in saline conditions. (2) Compatible solute accumulation (B — IS a mechanism) — to balance the low water potential created by vacuolar salt, the cytoplasm must accumulate osmotically active solutes that do not interfere with enzyme function. These 'compatible solutes' include: glycine betaine (a quaternary ammonium compound), proline (amino acid), trehalose (sugar), and pinitol (sugar alcohol). They protect proteins by preferential exclusion (they are excluded from protein surfaces, stabilizing native protein conformations). (3) Salt glands/bladder cells (C — IS a mechanism) — some halophytes have specialized epidermal structures for salt excretion: (a) Salt glands (e.g., Limonium, Tamarix, Spartina) — multicellular glandular trichomes that actively secrete NaCl solution onto the leaf surface, where it crystallizes. (b) Epidermal bladder cells (e.g., Mesembryanthemum crystallinum, ice plant) — giant modified trichomes that accumulate salt to very high concentrations, effectively removing it from metabolically active tissues. (4) NOT rapid transport to young leaves (D — NOT a mechanism, correct answer) — this would be harmful because young, growing leaves are most sensitive to salt damage. Instead, salt-tolerant plants: (a) Restrict Na+ loading into the xylem (minimizing transport to shoots). (b) Retrieve Na+ from the xylem sap in the root using HKT1 (High-affinity Potassium Transporter) class I transporters, which selectively take up Na+ from the xylem and redirect it to root vacuoles. (c) Preferentially accumulate salt in OLDER leaves (which will eventually senesce and be shed, removing the salt). These strategies protect the vulnerable growing tissues.

questions.question:
Match the following experimental techniques used in plant physiology with what they measure:
(P) Scholander pressure chamber
(Q) Porometer
(R) Aphid stylet technique
(S) Potometer

1. Measures the rate of water uptake by a cut shoot, which approximates transpiration rate
2. Measures xylem water potential (tension) of a shoot or leaf
3. Measures stomatal conductance or aperture by assessing gas exchange through the leaf surface
4. Allows collection of pure phloem sap and measurement of sieve tube turgor pressure
questions.explanation: These four techniques are workhorses of plant water relations research: (1) Scholander pressure chamber (P-2) — measures xylem water potential. A cut shoot or leaf is placed in a sealed chamber with the cut end protruding. Gas pressure is applied until xylem sap reappears at the cut surface. The balancing pressure = -Ψw of the xylem. Developed by Scholander et al. (1965). Standard field instrument for measuring plant water status. (2) Porometer (Q-3) — measures stomatal conductance (or its inverse, stomatal resistance) by quantifying gas exchange through the leaf surface. Types include: (a) Transit porometer — measures time for humidity to increase from a set point to a higher point in a chamber clamped to the leaf. Faster increase = more open stomata. (b) Steady-state porometer — maintains a constant humidity differential and measures the water vapor flux. (c) Infrared gas analyzer (IRGA)-based systems — measure CO2 and H2O exchange simultaneously (e.g., LI-COR LI-6400/LI-6800). These provide photosynthesis rate and stomatal conductance in one measurement. (3) Aphid stylet technique (R-4) — aphids insert their stylets into individual sieve tube elements. After severing the aphid body, phloem sap exudes from the cut stylet under positive pressure. This allows: (a) collection of pure, uncontaminated phloem sap for compositional analysis, (b) measurement of sieve tube turgor pressure by connecting the stylet to a pressure transducer. This technique provides the most direct access to intact sieve tube physiology. (4) Potometer (S-1) — measures the rate of water uptake by a cut shoot placed in a sealed water reservoir. As the shoot transpires, it draws water from the reservoir, and the rate of water uptake (measured by movement of a meniscus in a graduated capillary) approximates the transpiration rate. Simple but effective classroom and research instrument. Note: water uptake slightly underestimates transpiration because some absorbed water is retained for growth.

questions.question: The efficiency of water use in C4 plants is approximately twice that of C3 plants. This is primarily because C4 plants:
options: Have thicker cuticles that prevent all transpiration
Lack stomata and absorb CO2 through the root system

Can partially close stomata while maintaining high photosynthetic rates because the CO2-concentrating mechanism (C4 cycle) elevates CO2 around rubisco in bundle sheath cells — this allows rubisco to operate efficiently at lower intercellular CO2 concentrations, meaning stomata can be less open (reducing transpiration) without proportionally reducing photosynthesis, giving C4 plants higher water-use efficiency (WUE)
Photosynthesize only at night when transpiration is minimal
questions.explanation: The superior water-use efficiency of C4 plants is a major competitive advantage in warm, water-limited environments: (1) C4 CO2-concentrating mechanism — in C4 plants, initial CO2 fixation occurs in mesophyll cells by PEP carboxylase (which has high CO2 affinity and no oxygenase activity). The 4-carbon product (malate or aspartate) is transported to bundle sheath cells, where it is decarboxylated, releasing CO2 that is refixed by rubisco. This effectively pumps CO2 from the mesophyll to the bundle sheath, creating CO2 concentrations 5-10 times higher than atmospheric around rubisco. (2) Reduced stomatal aperture — because PEP carboxylase has a much higher affinity for CO2 (HCO3-) than rubisco, C4 mesophyll cells can draw down intercellular CO2 to very low levels (5-10 ppm vs. 100-200 ppm in C3 leaves). This means C4 plants can maintain the same or higher photosynthetic rate with stomata partially closed, reducing the CO2 diffusion pathway while still providing sufficient CO2 for PEP carboxylase. (3) WUE comparison — water-use efficiency (defined as moles CO2 fixed per mole H2O transpired, or grams dry matter per kg water transpired) is approximately: C3 plants: 1-3 g dry matter per kg water (WUE ~1.5-2.5 mmol CO2/mol H2O). C4 plants: 2-5 g dry matter per kg water (WUE ~3-5 mmol CO2/mol H2O). CAM plants: 5-10 g dry matter per kg water (WUE ~6-12 mmol CO2/mol H2O). (4) Suppressed photorespiration — the high CO2 around rubisco in bundle sheath cells virtually eliminates photorespiration (rubisco oxygenase activity), further improving carbon gain efficiency. C4 plants do have cuticles and stomata (A, B are wrong), and they photosynthesize during the day (D describes CAM, not C4).

questions.question: Iron (Fe) is an essential micronutrient, but its availability in aerobic soils is extremely limited because Fe3+ forms insoluble hydroxides at neutral to alkaline pH. Plants have evolved two strategies to acquire iron from the soil. Strategy I (used by non-grass plants) involves:
options: Secretion of phytosiderophores (mugineic acid family) that chelate Fe3+ in the rhizosphere, followed by uptake of the intact Fe3+-phytosiderophore complex by a specific transporter (YS1)
Direct uptake of insoluble Fe(OH)3 particles by phagocytosis through root cells
Passive diffusion of Fe2+ through non-selective cation channels without any active mechanisms

Acidification of the rhizosphere by H+-ATPases (lowering pH to increase Fe3+ solubility), reduction of Fe3+ to the more soluble Fe2+ by a plasma membrane-bound ferric chelate reductase (FRO2), and uptake of Fe2+ by the divalent metal transporter IRT1 — all three components are upregulated under iron deficiency
questions.explanation: Iron acquisition strategies in plants are divided into Strategy I (non-grasses) and Strategy II (grasses): (1) Strategy I (non-grass plants — eudicots and non-grass monocots) — a three-component system: (a) Rhizosphere acidification — plasma membrane H+-ATPases (AHA2 in Arabidopsis) pump protons into the rhizosphere, lowering soil pH. At lower pH, Fe3+ solubility increases (Fe3+ is 1000× more soluble at pH 3 than at pH 7). (b) Ferric reduction — FRO2 (Ferric Reductase Oxidase 2), an NADPH-dependent transmembrane reductase, reduces Fe3+ to Fe2+ at the root surface. This is the rate-limiting step. Fe2+ is much more soluble than Fe3+. (c) Fe2+ uptake — IRT1 (Iron-Regulated Transporter 1), a ZIP family divalent metal transporter, takes up Fe2+ into the root epidermal cells. IRT1 also transports Zn2+, Mn2+, Cd2+, and Co2+ (which is why iron-deficient plants often accumulate these metals). (d) Regulation — all three components are strongly upregulated under Fe deficiency, regulated by the bHLH transcription factor FIT (FER-LIKE IRON DEFICIENCY-INDUCED TRANSCRIPTION FACTOR) and its partners (bHLH38/39/100/101). (2) Strategy II (grasses — Poaceae) — described in option A. Grasses synthesize and secrete phytosiderophores (PS, mugineic acid family compounds derived from S-adenosylmethionine) into the rhizosphere. PS chelate Fe3+ with very high affinity. The intact Fe3+-PS complex is taken up by the YS1 (YELLOW STRIPE 1) transporter. Rice uniquely uses both strategies. Phagocytosis (B) does not occur in plant cells. Passive diffusion (C) is insufficient for the extremely low Fe2+ concentrations in soil solution.

questions.question: During autumn leaf senescence, deciduous trees reabsorb valuable nutrients from senescing leaves before abscission. Which nutrient is reabsorbed most efficiently (highest percentage recovered) and which is NOT significantly reabsorbed?
options: Calcium is most efficiently reabsorbed; nitrogen is left behind in falling leaves
All nutrients are reabsorbed with equal efficiency during senescence
Magnesium is the most mobile nutrient; potassium remains fixed in cell walls

Nitrogen and phosphorus are reabsorbed most efficiently (50-80% recovered via phloem remobilization) — calcium, however, is largely immobile in the phloem because it is bound in cell walls (as calcium pectate in the middle lamella) and cannot be redistributed, so senescing leaves retain most of their calcium content
questions.explanation: Nutrient remobilization during senescence is an important conservation strategy for deciduous plants: (1) Nitrogen remobilization — nitrogen is the most efficiently reabsorbed nutrient during leaf senescence. Leaf proteins (especially rubisco, which constitutes 25-50% of total leaf nitrogen) are systematically degraded by proteases during senescence. The resulting amino acids (primarily glutamine and asparagine) are loaded into the phloem and transported to perennial storage tissues (bark, wood parenchyma, roots) for winter storage. Recovery: typically 50-80% of leaf nitrogen is reabsorbed. This recovered nitrogen is remobilized the following spring to support new leaf growth. (2) Phosphorus remobilization — phosphorus is also efficiently recovered. Phospholipids, nucleic acids, and phosphorylated metabolites are degraded, and inorganic Pi is loaded into the phloem. Recovery: 50-80% of leaf phosphorus. (3) Calcium immobility — calcium is largely NOT reabsorbed because: (a) Calcium pectate — Ca2+ cross-links pectin chains in the middle lamella and cell walls (the 'egg-box' model). This structural calcium is essentially fixed and cannot be solubilized and remobilized. (b) Calcium oxalate — calcium is often sequestered as insoluble calcium oxalate crystals in vacuoles, which cannot be remobilized. (c) Phloem immobility — calcium is generally phloem-immobile because high Ca2+ concentrations in sieve tubes would cause callose precipitation and sieve plate plugging. (d) Result — fallen autumn leaves contain nearly 100% of their original calcium content. (4) Other nutrients — potassium (highly mobile, 50-70% recovered), magnesium (moderately mobile, 30-50% recovered), sulfur (moderately mobile, 30-50% recovered), iron and manganese (immobile, not significantly recovered). (5) Visual evidence — autumn leaf color changes partly result from nutrient reabsorption: green chlorophyll is degraded (to recover N and Mg), revealing underlying carotenoids (yellow/orange) and newly synthesized anthocyanins (red/purple).

questions.question: Xylem sap in intact transpiring plants is under negative pressure (tension). What prevents dissolved gases from coming out of solution and forming bubbles (cavitation) under normal conditions?
options: Xylem sap contains no dissolved gases whatsoever
The xylem conducts water at positive pressure at all times
Active pumping by living xylem cells removes all gases from the sap

The cohesive strength of water and the small diameter of xylem conduits — water under tension in narrow, smooth-walled conduits resists cavitation because homogeneous nucleation (spontaneous bubble formation) requires extremely negative pressures (below -100 MPa), far exceeding physiological xylem tensions; cavitation in plants typically occurs by heterogeneous nucleation (air seeding through pit membranes) at much less negative pressures
questions.explanation: Understanding why xylem water columns don't routinely cavitate is key to the cohesion-tension theory: (1) Homogeneous nucleation — in pure, degassed water confined in smooth-walled tubes, bubble formation (cavitation) requires extremely negative pressures, theoretically below -100 MPa to -140 MPa. This is because creating a bubble requires overcoming the intermolecular cohesive forces (hydrogen bonds) that hold liquid water together. In narrow conduits, the small volume makes spontaneous nucleation even less likely (lower probability of a nucleation event per unit volume). Plant xylem tensions rarely exceed -10 MPa (most are -0.5 to -3 MPa under normal conditions), well within the metastable range of liquid water. (2) Heterogeneous nucleation — in practice, cavitation in plants occurs at much less negative pressures than predicted for homogeneous nucleation. This is because cavitation is triggered by 'air seeding' — air being pulled through pit membrane pores from an adjacent air-filled space (embolized vessel, intercellular space, or atmosphere at a wound). The air-seeding pressure depends on pit membrane pore diameter: ΔP = 4T/D (T = surface tension, D = pore diameter). For typical angiosperm pit membrane pores (5-20 nm), air seeding occurs at -1 to -10 MPa. (3) Conduit diameter — narrow conduits are more resistant to cavitation because: (a) smaller volume reduces nucleation probability, (b) if cavitation does occur, the embolism is confined to a single small conduit, and (c) repair by refilling is easier in narrow conduits. This is another aspect of the safety-efficiency trade-off. (4) Xylem sap does contain dissolved gases (A is wrong), is under negative pressure (B is wrong), and living cells cannot remove gases from the dead xylem conduits (C is wrong). (5) Refilling — some plants can refill embolized vessels by generating local positive pressures (root pressure, osmotic pumping by xylem parenchyma) that push air back into solution.

questions.question: A researcher cultures Arabidopsis plants hydroponically with 15N-labeled NO3- and measures 15N incorporation into different organs over time. After 24 hours, 15N is detected in shoots as glutamine > asparagine > glutamate. This pattern indicates:
options: That nitrate is not assimilated but stored directly in vacuoles
That nitrogen is transported as inorganic nitrate only, without any conversion

That the roots assimilated NO3- into amino acids before export to the shoot — nitrate reductase converts NO3- to NO2- in the cytoplasm, nitrite reductase converts NO2- to NH4+ in plastids, and glutamine synthetase (GS) combines NH4+ with glutamate to form glutamine; the predominance of glutamine in shoot 15N reflects its role as the primary nitrogen transport amino acid in the xylem and phloem
That 15N was incorporated through nitrogen fixation by endophytic bacteria
questions.explanation: Nitrogen assimilation and transport is a fundamental process in plant nutrition: (1) Nitrate assimilation pathway — the sequential reduction of NO3- to NH4+ and its incorporation into amino acids: (a) Nitrate reductase (NR): NO3- + NAD(P)H + H+ → NO2- + NAD(P)+ + H2O. Location: cytoplasm. Requires molybdenum cofactor. (b) Nitrite reductase (NiR): NO2- + 6 Fd(red) + 8H+ → NH4+ + 6 Fd(ox) + 2H2O. Location: plastids (chloroplasts in leaves, leucoplasts in roots). Uses ferredoxin as electron donor. (c) Glutamine synthetase (GS): glutamate + NH4+ + ATP → glutamine + ADP + Pi. The primary NH4+ assimilation enzyme. Two isoforms: GS1 (cytoplasmic, important in roots and senescing tissues) and GS2 (plastid, important in leaves for photorespiratory NH4+ reassimilation).
