(d) GOGAT (glutamine:2-oxoglutarate aminotransferase): glutamine + 2-oxoglutarate + 2 Fd(red) → 2 glutamate + 2 Fd(ox). Regenerates glutamate for the GS reaction and produces net glutamate. (2) GS/GOGAT cycle — together, GS and GOGAT form a cycle: NH4+ is assimilated by GS into glutamine, then one amino group is transferred to 2-oxoglutarate by GOGAT to produce two glutamate molecules — one is recycled for GS, the other provides amino groups for transamination to other amino acids. (3) Transport forms — glutamine is the primary organic nitrogen transport form because it has two nitrogen atoms per molecule (high N:C ratio) and is chemically stable. Asparagine (also 2N per molecule) is the next most abundant. These amino acids are loaded into the xylem in roots and transported to shoots in the transpiration stream. (4) Site of assimilation — varies by species. In many herbaceous plants and crops, much NO3- assimilation occurs in roots before export. In some species (especially trees), NO3- may be transported to leaves for assimilation. The experimental finding of glutamine as the primary labeled form in shoots confirms root assimilation followed by transport. Direct vacuolar storage (A), inorganic transport only (B), and bacterial fixation (D) do not explain the amino acid labeling pattern.

questions.question: Carnivorous plants like Nepenthes (tropical pitcher plants) trap and digest insects primarily to supplement their nutrition with:
options: Carbon, because they cannot photosynthesize
Water, because they grow in arid deserts

Nitrogen (and phosphorus) — carnivorous plants are typically autotrophic (photosynthetic) and grow in nutrient-poor habitats (acidic bogs, peat swamps, nutrient-leached tropical soils); insect digestion provides supplemental nitrogen and phosphorus that are scarce in these substrates, while carbon is obtained through normal photosynthesis
Oxygen, because their roots are permanently submerged
questions.explanation: Carnivorous plants are among the most fascinating examples of nutritional adaptation in plants: (1) Photosynthetic autotrophs — all carnivorous plants are photosynthetic. They produce their own carbohydrates through normal C3 photosynthesis. Carnivory does NOT replace photosynthesis — it supplements mineral nutrition. (2) Nutrient-poor habitats — carnivorous plants typically grow in habitats with extremely low mineral nutrient availability: acidic sphagnum bogs, peat swamps, white sand savannas, tepuis (table-top mountains in Venezuela), and nutrient-leached tropical soils. In these habitats, nitrogen and phosphorus are the most limiting nutrients. (3) Nutritional benefit — insect digestion provides: (a) Nitrogen: proteins in insect bodies are broken down to amino acids by digestive enzymes (proteases, esterases) secreted into the pitcher fluid or on glandular surfaces. Nitrogen absorption can account for 10-80% of total plant nitrogen depending on prey capture rate. (b) Phosphorus: from insect exoskeletons (chitin contains P) and internal tissues. (c) Other minerals: K, Ca, Mg, Fe from prey tissues. (4) Digestive mechanisms — vary by genus: (a) Nepenthes/Sarracenia (pitchers): modified leaves forming fluid-filled pitfalls; digestive glands secrete proteases, esterases, ribonucleases. (b) Drosera (sundews): glandular trichomes produce sticky mucilage and digestive enzymes; leaves curl around trapped prey. (c) Dionaea (Venus flytrap): snap-trap mechanism with trigger hairs; digestive glands on inner trap surface. (d) Utricularia (bladderworts): aquatic suction traps that capture microorganisms in <1 ms. (5) Cost of carnivory — modified leaves for trapping have reduced photosynthetic area, creating a cost-benefit trade-off. Carnivory is advantageous only in nutrient-poor, high-light habitats where the nitrogen gain from prey exceeds the photosynthetic cost of maintaining traps. They are not non-photosynthetic (A), they grow in wet habitats (B is wrong), and oxygen acquisition (D) is not the primary purpose.

questions.question: A researcher suspects that a newly discovered Arabidopsis mutant has impaired aquaporin function in root cell membranes. To test this, the most informative experiment would be to:
options: Measure leaf color to assess chlorophyll content
Count the number of root hairs per centimeter of root length

Measure root hydraulic conductivity (Lp) using a root pressure probe or osmotic step-change experiment — compare Lp in the mutant vs. wild type, and also treat wild-type roots with HgCl2 (a known aquaporin inhibitor); if the mutant has impaired aquaporins, its Lp should be significantly reduced compared to wild type, and should be similar to HgCl2-treated wild type
Analyze seed germination rate in the mutant vs. wild type
questions.explanation: Testing aquaporin function requires measuring membrane water permeability: (1) Root hydraulic conductivity — Lp (hydraulic conductivity) is a measure of how easily water flows through root tissues. It reflects the collective water permeability of all membranes in the radial pathway from soil to xylem. Since aquaporins provide the major pathway for transmembrane water flow, reduced aquaporin function should directly reduce Lp. (2) Measurement methods — (a) Root pressure probe: a microcapillary attached to a pressure transducer is sealed to the cut end of a detopped root system. Applied pressure changes or osmotic step-changes in the bathing solution cause water flow, and Lp is calculated from the flow rate and driving force. (b) Osmotic step-change: transferring roots from one solution to another with different osmolarity causes a rapid volume change (measured by flow into/out of the root). The rate of this response is proportional to Lp. (c) High-pressure flow meter (HPFM): applies known pressures and measures resulting flow rates. (3) HgCl2 control — mercuric chloride (HgCl2) is a classic aquaporin inhibitor. It binds to cysteine residues near the pore of many aquaporin isoforms, blocking water flow. If the mutant's reduced Lp phenotype is similar to HgCl2-treated wild type, this strongly suggests the mutant's defect is in aquaporin function. Additionally, if HgCl2 has no further effect on the mutant's Lp (already reduced), this confirms that the same pathway is affected. (4) Complementary experiments — reversibility with beta-mercaptoethanol (which reduces Hg-S bonds and restores aquaporin function), molecular characterization of the mutation (which aquaporin gene is affected), and cell-level measurements using stopped-flow spectrophotometry on isolated protoplasts. (5) Leaf color (A), root hair count (B), and germination rate (D) do not directly measure aquaporin function.

questions.question: Sucrose is the primary transport sugar in the phloem of most plant species. The enzyme invertase, which cleaves sucrose into glucose and fructose, plays a critical role in phloem unloading at sink tissues. Cell wall invertase (cwINV) located in the apoplast of sink tissues promotes phloem unloading by:
options: Converting sucrose to starch directly in the sieve tube elements
Transporting sucrose across the plasma membrane of sink cells

Hydrolyzing sucrose in the apoplast to maintain a steep sucrose concentration gradient between the sieve tube (high sucrose) and the apoplast (low sucrose) — this gradient drives continued sucrose efflux from the phloem into the apoplast; the resulting hexoses (glucose and fructose) are then taken up by sink cells via hexose transporters, providing carbon and energy for growth and storage
Blocking phloem sap flow to prevent sugar from leaving the sieve tubes
questions.explanation: Phloem unloading mechanisms at sink tissues are critical for carbon allocation: (1) Apoplastic unloading — in many sink tissues (seeds, fruits, storage organs), sucrose is released from sieve tube elements into the apoplast. Cell wall invertase (cwINV) in the apoplast immediately cleaves arriving sucrose into glucose and fructose. This hydrolysis maintains a low sucrose concentration in the apoplast, keeping the concentration gradient steep between the sieve tube lumen (high sucrose) and the apoplast (low sucrose). This gradient drives continued sucrose efflux from the phloem. (2) Hexose uptake — the glucose and fructose produced by cwINV are taken up by sink cells via monosaccharide transporters (STPs — Sugar Transport Proteins, which are H+/hexose symporters). These hexoses are then metabolized for energy (respiration), growth (cell wall synthesis), or converted to storage forms (starch in amyloplasts, fats in oil bodies). (3) Source of driving force — by continuously removing sucrose from the apoplast (converting it to hexoses), cwINV prevents sucrose from accumulating and equilibrating with the phloem. This maintains the turgor pressure differential between source and sink predicted by the Munch pressure-flow hypothesis. (4) Developmental regulation — cwINV activity is high in rapidly growing and metabolically active sink tissues. It is a major determinant of sink strength. Transgenic plants with increased cwINV in specific sinks show enhanced carbon allocation to those organs. (5) Alternative unloading — symplastic unloading (through plasmodesmata, without membrane crossing) occurs in some sinks (root tips, vegetative storage tissues). In this case, sucrose moves directly from sieve tubes through plasmodesmata into sink cells, where vacuolar or cytoplasmic invertases cleave it. CwINV does not convert sucrose to starch (A), does not transport sucrose (B), and does not block flow (D).

questions.question: Transpiration rate is influenced by multiple environmental factors. Which factor has the MOST direct effect on stomatal aperture and therefore on transpiration?
options: Light intensity — blue light activates phototropin receptors on guard cells, which stimulate plasma membrane H+-ATPases to pump protons out, hyperpolarizing the membrane and driving K+ influx through voltage-gated channels, leading to osmotic water uptake, guard cell swelling, and stomatal opening; this is why transpiration increases dramatically when light is available
Soil type and mineral composition
Atmospheric nitrogen concentration
The gravitational pull on xylem sap columns
questions.explanation: Light is the primary environmental signal that controls stomatal opening and transpiration: (1) Blue light response — guard cells have phototropin receptors (phot1, phot2) that detect blue light. Activation of phototropins triggers a signaling cascade: phototropin autophosphorylation → 14-3-3 protein binding → activation of plasma membrane H+-ATPase (via phosphorylation of the C-terminal autoinhibitory domain) → H+ efflux → membrane hyperpolarization → opening of voltage-gated inward K+ channels (KAT1/KAT2) → K+ influx → Cl- and malate accumulation → decreased Ψs → osmotic water influx → increased turgor → stomatal opening. (2) Red light response — red light also promotes stomatal opening, mainly through photosynthesis in guard cell chloroplasts and in mesophyll cells. Guard cell photosynthesis reduces intercellular CO2, which triggers opening. Mesophyll photosynthesis reduces leaf Ci (intercellular CO2), also promoting opening. (3) Quantitative effect — in most C3 plants, transpiration rate is 5-10 times higher during the day than at night, primarily due to light-driven stomatal opening. Moving from darkness to full sunlight can increase stomatal conductance by 5-20 fold within 15-30 minutes. (4) Interaction with other factors — while humidity/VPD (vapor pressure deficit), temperature, CO2 concentration, and plant water status also affect stomatal aperture, light is the dominant stimulus for opening under non-stressed conditions. Without light, stomata remain mostly closed regardless of other favorable conditions. (5) Other factors listed — soil type (B) affects water availability but not stomatal aperture directly, atmospheric N2 (C) has no effect on stomata, and gravity (D) affects xylem water columns but not stomatal regulation.

questions.question: In symplastic phloem loading, sucrose moves from mesophyll cells into the sieve element-companion cell (SE-CC) complex through plasmodesmata. In species that use the 'polymer trapping' mechanism, how is the concentration gradient maintained to drive symplastic loading?
options: Sucrose entering the intermediary (companion) cells through plasmodesmata is converted to raffinose and stachyose — these larger raffinose-family oligosaccharides (RFOs) cannot diffuse back through the narrow plasmodesmata connecting intermediary cells to mesophyll cells, effectively trapping them in the SE-CC complex and maintaining a diffusion gradient for continued sucrose entry
Active pumps in the sieve tube push sucrose backward into mesophyll cells
Callose permanently seals all plasmodesmata after initial loading
Invertase in companion cells converts sucrose to glucose, which diffuses back to mesophyll
questions.explanation: The polymer trapping mechanism is an elegant solution for symplastic phloem loading: (1) The problem — in symplastic loading, sucrose moves from mesophyll to the SE-CC complex through plasmodesmata (without crossing any membrane). For net movement to occur, there must be a concentration gradient. But how can sucrose concentration be higher in the SE-CC complex than in mesophyll cells if they are connected by open plasmodesmata? Simple accumulation would equilibrate. (2) Polymer trapping solution — in species with intermediary cells (specialized companion cells, found in ~50% of plant families), the solution involves sugar conversion: (a) Sucrose moves from mesophyll through plasmodesmata into intermediary cells (down its concentration gradient). (b) In intermediary cells, sucrose is converted to raffinose (trisaccharide = galactose + sucrose) by galactinol synthase and raffinose synthase, and further to stachyose (tetrasaccharide = galactose + raffinose) by stachyose synthase. (c) The key: plasmodesmata between mesophyll and intermediary cells have a size exclusion limit that allows sucrose (MW 342) to pass but BLOCKS raffinose (MW 504) and stachyose (MW 666). The larger RFOs are trapped in the SE-CC complex. (3) Concentration gradient — because sucrose is continuously converted to RFOs (which cannot diffuse back), sucrose concentration in intermediary cells remains low relative to mesophyll. This maintains the diffusion gradient driving continued sucrose entry. (4) Species examples — polymer trapping is common in families like Cucurbitaceae (squash, melon), Lamiaceae, Scrophulariaceae, and Oleaceae. These species transport RFOs (raffinose + stachyose) as their primary phloem sugars, rather than sucrose. (5) Plasmodesmata structure — plasmodesmata at the mesophyll-intermediary cell interface are particularly abundant and have a branched structure on the intermediary cell side, consistent with high-flux but size-selective transport. Active pumps pushing sucrose back (B) would oppose loading, permanent callose sealing (C) would block all transport, and invertase conversion (D) would reduce, not enhance, loading.

questions.question: The proton motive force generated by H+-ATPases on plant cell plasma membranes is used to drive secondary active transport. The uptake of sucrose into companion cells during apoplastic phloem loading is mediated by:
options: A sucrose/H+ symporter (cotransporter) such as SUT1/SUC2 — the H+-ATPase pumps protons out of the cell, creating both a pH gradient (acidic outside) and an electrical gradient (negative inside); the SUT1 transporter couples the thermodynamically favorable return of H+ down its electrochemical gradient with the energetically unfavorable uptake of sucrose against its concentration gradient, achieving sucrose accumulation to 600-900 mM in sieve tubes
Simple diffusion through the lipid bilayer without any transporter
An ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter that directly hydrolyzes ATP to import sucrose
Pinocytosis (vesicle-mediated endocytosis of apoplastic solution)
questions.explanation: Apoplastic phloem loading via H+/sucrose symport is the dominant mechanism in most crop plants: (1) H+-ATPase — plasma membrane H+-ATPases (P-type ATPases of the AHA family) are the primary active transporters in plant cells. They pump H+ out of the cell at the expense of ATP hydrolysis (1 H+ per ATP), creating: (a) a pH gradient (ΔpH ≈ 1.5-2 units, pH ~5.5 outside vs. ~7.2 inside), and (b) a membrane potential (ΔΨ ≈ -120 to -180 mV, inside negative). Together, these constitute the proton motive force (PMF). (2) SUT1/SUC2 sucrose transporters — these are H+/sucrose symporters (cotransporters) that couple the energetically favorable return of H+ into the cell (down the PMF) with the transport of sucrose against its concentration gradient. The stoichiometry is typically 1 H+: 1 sucrose. SUT1 (in solanaceous species) and SUC2 (in Arabidopsis) are the main phloem-loading sucrose transporters. They are localized specifically to the plasma membrane of companion cells in minor vein phloem. (3) Accumulation — this secondary active transport can achieve sieve tube sucrose concentrations of 600-900 mM (20-30% w/v), compared to ~2-5 mM in the leaf apoplast. This represents a >100-fold concentration gradient across the companion cell membrane. (4) Evidence — sut1/suc2 mutants have dramatically impaired phloem loading, accumulate sugars in source leaves, and show reduced growth of sink organs. Antisense suppression of SUT1 in potato causes sugar accumulation in leaves and reduced tuber yield. (5) Sucrose cannot diffuse through the lipid bilayer (B) due to its size and polarity (MW 342, highly hydrophilic). ABC transporters (C) exist in plants but are not the primary sucrose loaders. Pinocytosis (D) does not occur at significant rates in plant cells.

questions.question: A researcher grows two groups of bean plants: one with mycorrhizal inoculation and one without (non-mycorrhizal controls). Both groups receive identical watering but NO supplemental phosphorus fertilizer. After 8 weeks, mycorrhizal plants have 3x higher shoot phosphorus content, 2x greater biomass, and extensive hyphal networks extending 5-8 cm from root surfaces. What is the best interpretation?
options: Mycorrhizal fungi synthesize phosphorus de novo from carbon and nitrogen
The mycorrhizal fungi are parasitic and the increased growth is due to a defense response

Mycorrhizal hyphae explore a much larger soil volume than roots alone, accessing phosphorus beyond the root depletion zone — this is especially important because phosphate ions (H2PO4-/HPO42-) are relatively immobile in soil, diffusing only 1-2 mm per day, so the root depletion zone develops rapidly; fungal hyphae bridging this zone dramatically enhance phosphorus acquisition
The increased phosphorus is from atmospheric deposition captured by aerial hyphae
questions.explanation: This experiment demonstrates the critical role of mycorrhizae in phosphorus nutrition: (1) Phosphorus immobility — phosphorus is the least mobile of the major plant nutrients in soil. H2PO4- (the form absorbed by plants at most soil pH values) diffuses through soil solution at only 0.3-3.3 x 10^-9 cm2/s. At these rates, Pi can only diffuse ~1-2 mm in a day. (2) Depletion zone — plant roots absorb Pi faster than it can diffuse through the soil to replace it. This creates a cylindrical depletion zone around each root, typically 1-2 mm wide, where Pi concentration drops to near zero. Roots cannot access Pi beyond this zone by diffusion alone. (3) Hyphal bridging — mycorrhizal hyphae (2-5 micrometers diameter) extend 5-15 cm beyond the root surface, far past the depletion zone. Their enormous surface area (hyphal length density can exceed 100 m per cm3 soil) effectively increases the absorptive volume of the root system by 10-1000 fold for phosphorus. (4) Quantitative impact — mycorrhizal plants typically have 2-5x higher tissue P content than non-mycorrhizal plants in low-P soils. In many natural ecosystems, >80% of plant phosphorus uptake is mediated by mycorrhizal hyphae. (5) Not parasitic — the relationship is mutualistic (the plant provides 4-20% of its photosynthetic carbon to the fungus). The growth increase is from improved nutrition, not defense. Fungi cannot synthesize phosphorus (A), they are not parasitic here (B), and aerial hyphae (D) are not a significant P source.

questions.question: Osmosis is the net movement of water across a selectively permeable membrane from a region of higher water potential to lower water potential. When a plant cell is placed in a hypertonic solution, which sequence of events occurs?
options: Water enters the cell, turgor increases, and the cell bursts (lysis)
The cell wall dissolves and the cell disintegrates

Water leaves the cell by osmosis, the vacuole shrinks, turgor pressure drops to zero, and the plasma membrane pulls away from the cell wall (plasmolysis) — the cell wall retains its shape because it is rigid, but the protoplast contracts, creating a gap between the plasma membrane and cell wall that fills with the external hypertonic solution entering through the permeable cell wall
Nothing happens because the cell wall prevents all water movement
questions.explanation: Plasmolysis is a fundamental concept in plant water relations: (1) Hypertonic environment — when the external solution has a more negative water potential (more negative Ψs) than the cell, water moves out of the cell by osmosis (from higher Ψw inside to lower Ψw outside). (2) Turgor loss — as water leaves, the vacuole shrinks and turgor pressure (Ψp) decreases. At incipient plasmolysis, Ψp = 0 and the plasma membrane just begins to detach from the cell wall. At this point, Ψw = Ψs (since Ψp = 0). (3) Plasmolysis — with continued water loss, the protoplast (everything inside the cell wall: plasma membrane, cytoplasm, vacuole) contracts further, pulling away from the rigid cell wall. The space between the plasma membrane and cell wall fills with the external solution (which can enter freely through the porous cell wall). (4) Cell wall role — the cell wall is permeable to water and most solutes (it is a porous matrix of cellulose, hemicellulose, and pectin with pores of ~5-10 nm). It does NOT prevent water movement. However, the cell wall IS rigid and maintains its shape even when the protoplast contracts. This is fundamentally different from animal cells, which lack walls and simply shrink (crenation in RBCs) or swell and lyse. (5) Reversibility — plasmolysis is reversible: placing the plasmolyzed cell in a hypotonic solution causes water re-entry, the protoplast re-expands, turgor is restored, and the plasma membrane re-establishes contact with the cell wall (deplasmolysis). However, severe or prolonged plasmolysis can damage the plasma membrane at the Hechtian strands (thin membrane connections to the wall), causing irreversible damage. Lysis (A) occurs in animal cells in hypotonic solutions, not in plant cells in hypertonic ones. The wall doesn't dissolve (B) or block water (D).

questions.question: The Hagen-Poiseuille equation predicts that the flow rate through a cylindrical tube is proportional to the fourth power of the tube radius (Q ∝ r⁴). This relationship has important implications for xylem transport because:
options: A vessel with twice the radius conducts 16 times more water per unit time per unit pressure gradient — this explains why wide earlywood vessels in ring-porous trees are dramatically more efficient for water transport than narrow latewood vessels, and why angiosperms (with wide vessels) generally have higher hydraulic conductivity than conifers (with narrow tracheids)
Wider vessels are always safer against cavitation
The equation shows that flow rate depends only on vessel length, not radius
Narrower vessels always conduct more water because they have more total surface area
questions.explanation: The Hagen-Poiseuille equation is central to understanding plant hydraulic architecture: (1) The equation — for laminar flow through a cylindrical tube: Q = (πr⁴ΔP)/(8ηL), where Q = volumetric flow rate, r = tube radius, ΔP = pressure difference, η = dynamic viscosity of the fluid, L = tube length. The critical feature is the r⁴ dependence: flow rate scales with the FOURTH POWER of radius. (2) Quantitative impact — doubling the radius increases flow by 2⁴ = 16-fold. A vessel 3x wider conducts 3⁴ = 81 times more water. This means a few large-diameter vessels can conduct vastly more water than many small-diameter ones occupying the same total cross-sectional area. (3) Angiosperm advantage — angiosperms have vessel elements that can be 20-500 micrometers in diameter, much wider than conifer tracheids (10-25 micrometers). Combined with perforation plates (reducing end-wall resistance), this gives angiosperms hydraulic conductivities 4-100x higher than conifers per unit sapwood area. This higher efficiency may have contributed to angiosperm ecological dominance. (4) Ring-porous trees — the dramatic difference between earlywood and latewood vessel size in ring-porous species means that earlywood vessels (100-300 micrometers diameter) may conduct >90% of total water flow, while latewood vessels (20-50 micrometers) contribute <10%. (5) Safety-efficiency trade-off — however, wider vessels are actually MORE vulnerable to cavitation (A says 'always safer' which is wrong — that's option B, which is incorrect). Wider vessels: (a) have more air-water interface at pit membranes (greater chance of air seeding), (b) are more vulnerable to freeze-thaw embolism (larger bubbles form in wider conduits), (c) represent a larger investment lost per cavitation event. This creates the well-known safety-efficiency trade-off: wide vessels are efficient but risky, narrow conduits are safe but less efficient. Option C (length only) contradicts the r⁴ term, and D (narrower is better) contradicts the physics.

questions.question: Boron (B) is an essential micronutrient unique among plant nutrients because its primary structural role involves:
options: Cross-linking rhamnogalacturonan II (RG-II) pectin molecules in the cell wall via borate diester bonds — boron bridges two RG-II monomers through their apiose residues, forming RG-II dimers that are critical for cell wall structural integrity and porosity; boron deficiency causes brittle cell walls, inhibited root elongation, and disrupted meristem function
Acting as a cofactor in the electron transport chain of mitochondria
Forming the central atom of the chlorophyll molecule
Serving as the primary osmoticum in guard cells during stomatal opening
questions.explanation: Boron is unique among essential plant nutrients because its primary function is structural rather than enzymatic: (1) RG-II cross-linking — rhamnogalacturonan II (RG-II) is a structurally complex pectic polysaccharide in the primary cell wall. RG-II has a conserved structure found in all vascular plants. It contains the rare sugar apiose, which has cis-diol groups that can form stable ester bonds with borate (B(OH)4-). A single borate ion bridges two apiose residues on adjacent RG-II molecules, creating a borate diester cross-link (RG-II-B-RG-II dimer). (2) Cell wall function — RG-II dimerization via boron is essential for: (a) normal cell wall strength and integrity, (b) proper cell wall porosity (the pectin network controls the effective pore size of the wall), (c) normal cell expansion (the pectin matrix must be properly cross-linked for regulated loosening during growth). Approximately 95-98% of cell wall boron is in RG-II borate diester complexes. (3) Deficiency symptoms — boron deficiency manifests primarily at growing points (meristems, developing organs) because these are sites of active cell wall synthesis: brittle, cracked stems and petioles; hollow stems and heart rot in beet/turnip; poor fruit set; inhibited root elongation; and death of shoot and root tips. Boron is relatively phloem-immobile in most species, so deficiency appears first in young tissues. (4) Narrow range — boron has the narrowest range between deficiency and toxicity of any essential mineral. Deficiency occurs below ~20 ppm tissue B; toxicity above ~100 ppm. This narrow window makes boron management challenging in agriculture. (5) Other roles — boron may also function in membrane transport, hormone signaling, and nucleic acid metabolism, but the RG-II cross-linking role is best established. Electron transport cofactor (B) describes iron/copper, chlorophyll central atom (C) is magnesium, and guard cell osmoticum (D) is potassium.

questions.question: To determine whether phloem transport occurs by mass flow (bulk flow of solution) rather than by diffusion or cytoplasmic streaming, a researcher should:
options: Introduce two different radioactive tracers (e.g., 14C-sucrose and 3H-water) simultaneously at the source and measure their arrival time at the sink — if transport is by mass flow, both tracers should move at the same velocity (carried together in the flowing solution); if by diffusion, the smaller water molecules should arrive faster than the larger sucrose molecules
Observe phloem cells under a light microscope only
Measure root growth rate in response to light
Count the number of sieve plates per unit length of stem
questions.explanation: Distinguishing mass flow from diffusion in phloem is a classic experimental design problem: (1) Mass flow prediction — in bulk flow (mass flow), all solutes and the solvent move together at the same velocity, regardless of molecular size. This is because the entire solution is flowing as a unit (like water in a pipe). If phloem transport is by mass flow, a large molecule (sucrose) and a small molecule (water) introduced at the same source location should arrive at a distant sink at the same time. (2) Diffusion prediction — in diffusion, molecules move independently according to their diffusion coefficients, which depend on molecular size. Smaller molecules (like water, MW 18) diffuse faster than larger ones (like sucrose, MW 342). If transport were by diffusion, tritiated water should arrive at the sink BEFORE 14C-sucrose. (3) Experimental results — such dual-tracer experiments (and their equivalents) have consistently shown that all components of phloem sap move at the same velocity, supporting mass flow. Typical velocities are 0.3-1.5 m/h — far too fast for diffusion (which would take years to transport sucrose even 1 meter). (4) Additional evidence for mass flow — (a) the velocity of phloem transport is independent of the concentration gradient (diffusion rate depends on concentration gradient), (b) transport velocity is consistent with pressure-driven flow through sieve tubes of measured dimensions, (c) all solutes in phloem sap (sugars, amino acids, hormones, ions) move at the same rate, (d) sieve tube turgor measurements show source-to-sink pressure gradients. (5) Why other options fail — microscopy (B) cannot measure transport velocity; root growth (C) is irrelevant; sieve plate counts (D) describe anatomy but don't distinguish transport mechanisms.

questions.question: During drought, plants accumulate compatible solutes in their cytoplasm to maintain turgor. Which of the following compounds serves as a compatible solute for osmotic adjustment?
options: Proline — this amino acid accumulates to high concentrations (up to 100 mM) in drought-stressed plant cells, lowering the cytoplasmic osmotic potential without inhibiting enzyme function; proline also acts as a molecular chaperone stabilizing protein structure, a ROS scavenger, and a source of carbon and nitrogen for recovery after stress relief
Sodium chloride in the cytoplasm at concentrations exceeding 500 mM
Free calcium ions at 10 mM or higher in the cytoplasm
Lignin monomers dissolved in the vacuolar sap
questions.explanation: Compatible solute accumulation (osmotic adjustment) is a key drought tolerance mechanism: (1) Definition — compatible solutes are small organic molecules that can accumulate to high concentrations in the cytoplasm without disrupting enzyme function or protein structure. They lower the osmotic potential (Ψs), allowing water retention and turgor maintenance under drought. (2) Proline — one of the most widespread compatible solutes in plants: (a) Accumulation — proline can increase 10-100 fold under drought, from ~5 mM to 100+ mM. Synthesis is upregulated via P5CS (delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate synthetase), which is induced by drought/ABA, while degradation (ProDH, proline dehydrogenase) is suppressed. (b) Osmotic function — high proline concentration lowers Ψs, helping cells retain water. (c) Protein stabilization — proline acts as a 'chemical chaperone' through preferential exclusion: it is excluded from protein surfaces, which stabilizes the native folded state by making unfolding thermodynamically unfavorable. (d) ROS scavenging — proline can react with and detoxify reactive oxygen species (hydroxyl radical, singlet oxygen), providing antioxidant protection during stress. (e) Post-stress recovery — after stress relief, proline is rapidly catabolized by ProDH/P5CDH in mitochondria, providing electrons to the ETC (energy), carbon skeletons, and nitrogen for recovery. (3) Other compatible solutes — glycine betaine (quaternary ammonium compound, common in Chenopodiaceae and grasses), trehalose (disaccharide), pinitol/mannitol (sugar alcohols), and raffinose-family oligosaccharides. (4) NaCl (B) is NOT compatible — high cytoplasmic Na+ (>100 mM) inhibits most enzymes. Free Ca2+ (C) at 10 mM would be toxic to cellular signaling (normal cytoplasmic Ca2+ is ~100 nM). Lignin monomers (D) are not osmolytes.

questions.question: The proton pump (H+-ATPase) on plant cell plasma membranes is analogous to the Na+/K+-ATPase in animal cells because both:
options: Transport sodium and potassium in the same stoichiometry
Are powered by the proton motive force rather than ATP

Generate the primary electrochemical gradient across the plasma membrane that drives all secondary active transport — in plants, the H+-ATPase creates the proton motive force (ΔpH + ΔΨ) used by H+/sucrose symporters, H+/amino acid symporters, H+/K+ symporters, and H+/anion antiporters; in animals, the Na+/K+-ATPase creates the Na+ gradient used by Na+/glucose symporters and other secondary transporters
Are located exclusively in mitochondrial membranes
questions.explanation: The plasma membrane H+-ATPase is the 'master transporter' of plant cells, functionally analogous to the Na+/K+-ATPase in animal cells: (1) Plants: H+-ATPase — P-type ATPase (AHA family, ~11 members in Arabidopsis). Pumps H+ OUT of the cell, creating: (a) Chemical gradient — ΔpH of ~1.5-2 units (cytoplasm pH ~7.2, apoplast pH ~5.5). (b) Electrical gradient — membrane potential of -120 to -180 mV (inside negative). Together = proton motive force (PMF). (2) Secondary transport — the PMF drives numerous secondary active transport processes: (a) H+/sucrose symport (SUT/SUC transporters) — phloem loading, sugar uptake. (b) H+/amino acid symport (AAP, LHT transporters) — amino acid uptake. (c) H+/K+ symport — potassium uptake via HAK/KUP transporters. (d) H+/NO3- symport (NRT1/NRT2) — nitrate uptake. (e) H+/Na+ antiport — Na+ exclusion from cytoplasm (SOS1). (f) H+/auxin symport (AUX1) — auxin influx in polar transport. (3) Animals: Na+/K+-ATPase — pumps 3 Na+ out and 2 K+ in per ATP. Creates the Na+ gradient used by: Na+/glucose symport (SGLT), Na+/amino acid symport, Na+/Ca2+ antiport, etc. (4) Functional analogy — both are primary active transporters that consume ATP to establish the electrochemical gradient that powers virtually all other membrane transport. They represent convergent evolution of the same energetic strategy: using ATP to create an ion gradient, then using that gradient to drive secondary transport of dozens of different substrates. (5) They do NOT transport the same ions in the same stoichiometry (A), they both use ATP directly rather than being powered by PMF (B — they CREATE the gradient), and they are plasma membrane-localized, not mitochondrial (D).

questions.question: Epiphytic plants growing on tree branches without soil contact face a unique challenge for water and mineral acquisition. Epiphytic orchids often have specialized aerial roots covered with velamen. The velamen is:
options: A multilayered sheath of dead, spongy cells with thickened walls that rapidly absorbs rainwater and dissolved minerals through capillary action — when wet, the velamen becomes translucent, allowing light to reach the chloroplast-containing cortex underneath; when dry, it acts as an insulating reflective layer reducing water loss from underlying living root tissues
A layer of mycorrhizal fungal tissue forming a permanent sheath
Living photosynthetic cells that perform CAM photosynthesis
A waxy cuticle identical to that on leaves
questions.explanation: Velamen is a remarkable adaptation in epiphytic orchid roots: (1) Structure — the velamen is a multilayered epidermis (typically 2-18 cell layers) covering the aerial roots of most epiphytic orchids. Velamen cells are dead at maturity, with thickened cell walls containing lignin and suberin in characteristic spiral or helical patterns. The walls have numerous pores and the cells are hollow, creating a sponge-like tissue. (2) Water absorption — when rain or dew wets the velamen, water is rapidly absorbed by capillary action through the porous dead cells. The velamen can absorb water equivalent to several times its dry weight within seconds. Absorbed water is then taken up by the living exodermis cells (the outermost living cell layer beneath the velamen) through aquaporins and osmotic gradients. (3) Mineral uptake — dissolved minerals in rainwater or leachate from bark and canopy are absorbed along with water. The exodermis cells selectively absorb minerals, similar to the endodermis in soil roots. (4) Light function — dry velamen cells are air-filled and appear silvery-white due to light reflection/refraction. Wet velamen becomes translucent as air is replaced by water, allowing light to reach the green cortical cells beneath. Many epiphytic orchid roots contain chloroplasts in their cortex and can photosynthesize (contributing 5-30% of total carbon fixation in some leafless orchid species). (5) Desiccation protection — when dry, the air-filled velamen acts as an insulating blanket that reduces water loss from living tissues beneath, reflects excess light and UV radiation, and reduces thermal load. It is not mycorrhizal tissue (B — though orchids do have mycorrhizae, the velamen is a plant tissue), not living photosynthetic cells (C — the velamen cells are dead; the cortex beneath has chloroplasts), and not a waxy cuticle (D — it is a multilayered tissue, not a surface coating).

questions.question: When a plant cell reaches full turgor in a hypotonic solution, net water movement ceases even though the solute potential (Ψs) is still negative. This is because:
options: All solutes have been expelled from the cell

The turgor pressure (Ψp) generated by the cell wall pushing back on the expanding protoplast exactly balances the negative solute potential, bringing the total water potential (Ψw = Ψs + Ψp) to zero (equal to that of the surrounding pure water) — at equilibrium, there is no water potential gradient to drive net water movement, even though the osmotic gradient still exists
The plasma membrane becomes completely impermeable to water
Aquaporins are all permanently closed by turgor-sensing mechanisms
questions.explanation: Understanding turgor equilibrium is fundamental to plant cell water relations: (1) Initial state — when a flaccid plant cell (Ψp ≈ 0) is placed in pure water (Ψw = 0): Cell Ψw = Ψs + Ψp = (negative) + 0 = negative. Since cell Ψw < external Ψw (0), water enters by osmosis. (2) Water entry and turgor buildup — as water enters, the protoplast swells and presses against the rigid cell wall. The cell wall resists expansion, generating turgor pressure (Ψp > 0) that pushes back on the protoplast. (3) Approach to equilibrium — turgor pressure increases as water continues to enter. Each increment of turgor raises the cell's total Ψw (making it less negative): Ψw = Ψs + Ψp. As turgor builds, the driving force for water entry (the difference between external and cell Ψw) decreases. (4) Equilibrium (full turgor) — net water movement ceases when the cell Ψw equals the external Ψw. If the external solution is pure water (Ψw = 0): 0 = Ψs + Ψp, therefore Ψp = -Ψs. The positive turgor pressure exactly balances the negative solute potential. Note: the osmotic gradient (Ψs) still exists — there are still more solutes inside than outside. But the turgor pressure counterbalances the osmotic driving force. (5) Cell wall role — this equilibrium is possible ONLY because plant cells have rigid walls that generate back-pressure. Animal cells lack walls and therefore cannot generate turgor. In a hypotonic solution, animal cells continue to swell until they lyse (no back-pressure to oppose water entry). This is why plants are turgid but not bursting — the wall provides the counterbalancing force. Solutes are not expelled (A), the membrane remains permeable (C), and aquaporins remain functional (D).

questions.question: The loading of sucrose into the phloem occurs specifically in the minor veins of source leaves. Minor veins differ from major veins in that they:
options: Are embedded in the leaf mesophyll and function primarily as collection and loading sites — minor veins have a high ratio of companion cells to sieve elements, companion cells often have wall ingrowths (transfer cell morphology) or branched plasmodesmata (intermediary cell morphology) specialized for efficient phloem loading, and are densely distributed so that no mesophyll cell is far from a vein
Are the midrib and primary veins that provide structural support only
Contain only xylem and no phloem elements
Are found only in monocot leaves, not in eudicot leaves
questions.explanation: Minor veins are the functional loading sites for phloem transport: (1) Vein hierarchy — leaf vasculature forms a hierarchical network: the midrib (1st order) branches into secondary veins (2nd order), then tertiary, quaternary, and eventually minor veins (highest order, typically 4th-7th order). Minor veins are the finest, most numerous vein endings embedded in the mesophyll. (2) Loading function — while major veins serve primarily as transport conduits (carrying phloem sap from the leaf to the stem), minor veins are the sites where sucrose is loaded from the mesophyll into the phloem. No mesophyll cell is typically more than 2-3 cells away from a minor vein, minimizing the distance sucrose must travel before loading. (3) Companion cell specialization — minor vein companion cells are morphologically specialized for loading: (a) Transfer cells — in apoplastic loaders (most crop plants), companion cells have elaborate wall ingrowths that amplify the plasma membrane surface area for H+/sucrose symport. (b) Intermediary cells — in symplastic loaders (polymer trapping), companion cells have extensive branched plasmodesmata connecting to mesophyll cells and contain enzymes for RFO synthesis. (c) Ordinary companion cells — in some species with passive symplastic loading. (4) High CC:SE ratio — minor veins have a higher ratio of companion cells to sieve elements compared to major veins, reflecting the intensive metabolic activity of loading (companion cells provide the energy for active transport). (5) Both monocots and eudicots — minor veins exist in both monocot leaves (parallel venation with cross-connecting minor veins) and eudicot leaves (reticulate venation with minor veins forming the finest network). Major veins primarily transport (B is partially right about support but wrong that this is the ONLY function and doesn't distinguish from minor veins), minor veins contain both xylem and phloem (C is wrong), and minor veins occur in all vascular plants (D is wrong).

questions.question: A researcher measures xylem sap composition in a plant growing with both NH4+ and NO3- available. The xylem sap contains high concentrations of organic acids (malate, citrate) and amino acids (glutamine, asparagine) but very low NO3-. When the same species is grown with NO3- only (no NH4+), xylem sap NO3- concentration increases dramatically. This indicates that:
options: The plant cannot absorb nitrate from the soil under any conditions
Ammonium inhibits all root metabolic activity and prevents any nitrogen transport

When NH4+ is available, roots preferentially assimilate it into amino acids locally, reducing the need to transport NO3- to the shoot for assimilation — NH4+ assimilation in roots via GS/GOGAT produces glutamine and other amino acids that are exported in the xylem; when only NO3- is available, root assimilation capacity is overwhelmed and excess NO3- is transported to shoots for leaf-based assimilation
NO3- is toxic and plants always exclude it from the xylem
questions.explanation: This experiment reveals the interplay between nitrogen form availability and assimilation site: (1) NH4+ preference — many plants preferentially absorb and assimilate NH4+ over NO3- when both are available: (a) NH4+ is already in the reduced form needed for amino acid synthesis (no energy-costly reduction step needed). (b) NH4+ assimilation via GS/GOGAT occurs readily in root plastids. (c) The energetic cost of NH4+ assimilation is lower than NO3- assimilation (NO3- requires 8 electrons for full reduction to NH4+ before GS/GOGAT can act). (2) Root assimilation — when NH4+ is abundant, roots can assimilate most of the absorbed nitrogen locally, exporting organic nitrogen (glutamine, asparagine, other amino acids) and organic acids (malate, citrate — needed as carbon skeletons and for charge balance) in the xylem sap. Little NO3- is transported because roots have sufficient reduced nitrogen from NH4+. (3) Shoot assimilation — when only NO3- is available, root nitrate reductase and nitrite reductase capacity may be insufficient to reduce all absorbed NO3-. Excess NO3- is loaded into the xylem and transported to leaves, where leaf nitrate reductase (using photosynthetically generated reductant) handles the reduction. The ratio of root vs. shoot NO3- assimilation varies by species: some (like many tree species) assimilate most NO3- in roots; others (like many grasses) transport significant NO3- to shoots. (4) Regulation — NH4+ availability downregulates the expression of high-affinity nitrate transporters (NRT2.1) and nitrate assimilatory genes in roots. This feedback prevents unnecessary NO3- uptake when reduced nitrogen is already available. (5) Plants can clearly absorb nitrate (A is wrong), NH4+ does not inhibit root metabolism (B is wrong), and NO3- is not inherently toxic at normal concentrations (D is wrong).

questions.question: Xylem-to-phloem transfer of water is an important process that links the two long-distance transport systems. This transfer occurs primarily in which part of the plant?
options: Only in the root tips where xylem and phloem terminate

In the leaves — as phloem sap is loaded with sucrose at the source, water potential in the sieve tubes drops below that of adjacent xylem, causing water to move osmotically from xylem to phloem through intervening cells; this lateral xylem-to-phloem water transfer provides the water that drives pressure-flow transport in the phloem
In the bark, through lenticels
Exclusively in root nodules during nitrogen fixation
questions.explanation: Xylem-to-phloem water transfer is a critical but often overlooked component of the integrated plant transport system: (1) The need for lateral transfer — the Munch pressure-flow model requires that water enters sieve tubes at the source end to generate turgor pressure. This water must come from somewhere: it comes from the xylem. (2) Mechanism — in source leaves: (a) Sucrose is actively loaded into the SE-CC complex (by apoplastic or symplastic loading), reaching concentrations of 0.3-0.9 M. (b) This high sucrose concentration creates a very negative Ψs (-0.7 to -2.5 MPa) in the sieve tubes. (c) The water potential of sieve tubes (Ψw = Ψs + Ψp) drops below that of the adjacent xylem (which has Ψs ≈ 0 MPa, Ψp = negative but less negative than phloem Ψs). (d) Water moves osmotically from xylem to phloem through the intervening cells (bundle sheath, phloem parenchyma). (3) Quantitative significance — phloem sap is ~80-90% water. All of this water ultimately comes from the xylem. In a rapidly growing plant, phloem water flow can represent 10-30% of total transpirational water flow. (4) Sink end — the reverse occurs at sinks: as sucrose is unloaded from sieve tubes, water potential rises and water moves osmotically from phloem back to xylem, completing the cycle. This returning water is then recirculated through the xylem. (5) Whole-plant integration — the xylem and phloem thus form a circulatory system: xylem carries water and minerals upward, phloem carries sugars and organic nutrients downward (and upward to growing shoot tips), and water cycles between the two systems via lateral transfer at sources and sinks. Transfer does not occur only at root tips (A), through lenticels (C), or in nodules (D).

questions.question: The concept of 'sink strength' determines how much photosynthate a particular organ receives from phloem transport. Sink strength is determined by:
options: Sink size (biomass of the organ) multiplied by sink activity (rate of sugar uptake and utilization per unit mass) — a large, metabolically active organ like a developing fruit has high sink strength because it both has substantial mass and actively imports and metabolizes sugars; modifying either component through breeding or genetic engineering can alter carbon allocation patterns
Only the physical distance from the nearest source leaf
The number of stomata on the sink organ surface
The total chlorophyll content of the sink tissue
questions.explanation: Sink strength is a central concept in understanding carbon partitioning in plants: (1) Definition — sink strength = sink size × sink activity. (a) Sink size — the physical mass or volume of the sink organ. A large fruit has greater sink size than a small axillary bud. (b) Sink activity — the rate of sugar import, unloading, and metabolism per unit mass. Rapidly dividing and growing tissues have high sink activity. Tissues actively converting sugars to storage compounds (starch, lipids, proteins) also have high activity. (2) Molecular determinants — sink activity depends on: (a) Phloem unloading capacity — the number and activity of sucrose transporters, invertases, and plasmodesmata at the phloem-sink interface. Cell wall invertase (cwINV) is particularly important for apoplastic unloading. (b) Metabolic rate — the rate at which imported sugars are metabolized (respiration, biosynthesis) or converted to storage forms. Starch synthesis in storage organs, cellulose synthesis in growing cells, and lipid synthesis in developing seeds all consume sugars and maintain the concentration gradient for continued import. (c) Transport infrastructure — the number and diameter of sieve tubes connecting the sink to source leaves. (3) Competition among sinks — when multiple sinks compete for photosynthate from the same source, sink strength determines allocation priority. Developing seeds typically have the highest priority (strong sinks), followed by roots, then vegetative shoot growth. (4) Practical applications — increasing sink strength is a major goal of crop improvement. For example: increasing cwINV expression in seeds enhances seed filling; overexpressing starch synthesis enzymes in tubers increases starch accumulation; altering sucrose transporter expression modifies carbon partitioning. (5) Distance (B) affects transport efficiency but is not the definition of sink strength. Stomata (C) and chlorophyll (D) are irrelevant to sink function.

questions.question: Potassium (K+) is the most abundant cation in plant cells and is required in large amounts. Which of the following is NOT a function of K+ in plants?
options: Stomatal regulation — K+ accumulation drives guard cell swelling and opening
Osmotic adjustment — K+ is the major osmoticum for cell expansion and turgor maintenance
Enzyme activation — K+ is a cofactor for over 60 enzymes including pyruvate kinase

A structural component of amino acids and proteins — in reality, K+ is NOT incorporated into organic molecules; unlike nitrogen and sulfur, potassium functions exclusively as a free ion (K+) in solution, serving osmotic, electrical, and catalytic roles without forming covalent bonds with organic molecules
questions.explanation: Potassium is unique among macronutrients because it remains as a free ion: (1) Stomatal regulation (A — TRUE function) — K+ accumulation in guard cells is the primary osmotic driver of stomatal opening. K+ influx (via KAT1/KAT2 channels) lowers guard cell Ψs, causing water entry and turgor-driven opening. K+ efflux (via GORK channel) drives stomatal closure. (2) Osmotic adjustment (B — TRUE function) — K+ is the major inorganic osmoticum in plant cells. High K+ concentration in vacuoles and cytoplasm maintains cell turgor. K+ is essential for cell expansion — rapidly elongating cells accumulate K+ to generate the turgor needed to expand the cell wall. K+ deficiency causes plants to wilt despite adequate water. (3) Enzyme cofactor (C — TRUE function) — K+ activates numerous enzymes: (a) Pyruvate kinase — requires K+ for activity. (b) Starch synthase — K+ promotes starch synthesis; K+ deficiency impairs starch accumulation. (c) Protein synthesis — K+ is required for ribosome function and polypeptide elongation. (d) Other — ATPases, dehydrogenases, and transferases all require K+ for optimal activity. K+ typically activates enzymes by stabilizing their active conformations. (4) NOT a structural component (D — FALSE, correct answer) — K+ is NOT covalently bonded into any organic molecule. Unlike N (in amino acids, nucleotides), S (in cysteine, methionine), P (in ATP, nucleic acids, phospholipids), and Mg (in chlorophyll), potassium exists exclusively as the free K+ ion. It functions through its ionic properties: charge, osmotic activity, and ability to bind non-covalently to enzyme active sites. This unique feature means K+ is highly mobile in plants (easily redistributed from old to young tissues via phloem) and its cellular concentration fluctuates dynamically. (5) Required amount — K+ typically comprises 1-5% of plant dry weight, making it the mineral nutrient required in the largest quantity.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a particular anion channel (SLAC1) in guard cells is necessary for ABA-induced stomatal closure. The best experimental approach is:
options: Apply ABA to wild-type plants and measure transpiration rate only

Compare stomatal closure responses to ABA in wild-type Arabidopsis vs. slac1 loss-of-function mutants — if SLAC1 is necessary, the mutant should show impaired stomatal closure in response to ABA; additionally, patch-clamp electrophysiology on isolated guard cell protoplasts can directly measure whether ABA activates S-type anion currents in wild type but not in slac1 mutants
Measure SLAC1 gene expression in root tips only
Grow plants in high CO2 and observe whether stomata close
questions.explanation: Testing whether SLAC1 is necessary for ABA-induced stomatal closure requires a combination of genetic and electrophysiological approaches: (1) Genetic approach — comparing wild-type and slac1 knockout mutants: (a) Treat both genotypes with exogenous ABA at identical concentrations. (b) Measure stomatal aperture by epidermal peels or thermal imaging (stomatal closure reduces transpirational cooling, raising leaf temperature). (c) Prediction: if SLAC1 is necessary, slac1 mutants should show reduced or absent stomatal closure in response to ABA. The original slac1 mutant characterization (Negi et al., 2008; Vahisalu et al., 2008) showed exactly this: slac1 mutants had impaired ABA-induced stomatal closure and exhibited a wilty phenotype under drought. (2) Electrophysiology — patch-clamp recording on guard cell protoplasts: (a) Isolate guard cell protoplasts from wild-type and slac1 leaves. (b) Apply ABA intracellularly or extracellularly. (c) Measure S-type anion channel currents (slow-activating, sustained anion efflux currents). (d) Prediction: ABA should activate S-type anion currents in wild-type protoplasts but not (or much less) in slac1 protoplasts. (3) Complementation — re-expressing SLAC1 in the slac1 mutant background should rescue both the stomatal closure response and the anion channel currents, confirming that the defect is specifically due to loss of SLAC1. (4) Reconstitution — expressing SLAC1 together with OST1/SnRK2.6 kinase in Xenopus oocytes reconstitutes ABA-activatable anion currents, demonstrating direct phosphorylation-dependent activation. (5) Measuring transpiration in wild type only (A) cannot determine whether SLAC1 is involved. Root tip expression (C) is irrelevant to guard cell function. High CO2 (D) tests a different closure pathway that may or may not require SLAC1.

questions.question: Embolism repair (refilling of cavitated xylem vessels) can occur in some plant species while surrounding vessels are still under tension. The proposed mechanism for this involves:
options: New vessel elements rapidly differentiating from cambial derivatives to replace embolized ones

Living xylem parenchyma cells adjacent to the embolized vessel actively secreting solutes (sugars, K+) into the vessel lumen, generating a local osmotic gradient that draws water in from surrounding functional xylem — this creates a localized positive pressure sufficient to dissolve and push out the air bubble, and the process requires metabolic energy from parenchyma cells
The embolized vessel simply remaining non-functional permanently
Atmospheric pressure forcing air out of the vessel through the roots
questions.explanation: Embolism repair is one of the most actively researched topics in plant hydraulics: (1) The paradox — for refilling to occur in a vessel surrounded by functional vessels under tension, there must be a mechanism to generate local positive pressure in the embolized vessel while maintaining negative pressure (tension) in adjacent functional vessels. The two must be hydraulically isolated during refilling. (2) Osmotic refilling hypothesis — the most widely accepted mechanism involves xylem parenchyma cells (ray parenchyma and axial parenchyma cells that are in contact with vessels through pit pairs): (a) Parenchyma cells detect the embolized (air-filled) vessel, possibly through changes in water potential or mechanical signals at pit membranes. (b) They actively secrete solutes (sugars from starch hydrolysis, K+, other ions) into the lumen of the embolized vessel through aquaporins and solute transporters. (c) The high solute concentration creates a negative water potential in the vessel lumen, causing osmotic water influx from adjacent living cells. (d) As water enters, it builds positive pressure that gradually compresses and dissolves the gas bubble. (3) Energy requirement — the process requires metabolic energy: ATP for H+-ATPases and solute transporters in parenchyma cells. Starch reserves in parenchyma cells provide the sugars. This is why living parenchyma cells are essential for refilling and why heartwood vessels (with dead parenchyma) cannot be refilled. (4) Isolation mechanism — the pit membranes between the refilling vessel and adjacent functioning vessels may provide the hydraulic isolation needed to prevent the positive refilling pressure from disrupting the tension in nearby vessels. Alternatively, vapor-filled vessels may be isolated by air-water menisci at pit membranes. (5) New vessel formation (A) occurs but is too slow (days to weeks) for rapid recovery. Permanent loss of function (C) does occur in some cases but is not universal. Atmospheric pressure (D) cannot push air out of a vessel that is sealed within the xylem.

questions.question: Phosphorus deficiency is among the most common nutrient deficiencies in agriculture worldwide. Plants respond to low phosphorus availability by:
options: Shutting down all root growth and allocating resources exclusively to shoots
Increasing shoot-to-root ratio to maximize light capture over nutrient acquisition

Increasing root hair length and density, secreting organic acids (citrate, malate) and phosphatases into the rhizosphere, upregulating high-affinity Pi transporters (PHT1 family), and forming cluster roots (proteoid roots) in some species — these responses collectively maximize phosphorus acquisition from the soil by increasing root surface area, solubilizing bound phosphorus, hydrolyzing organic phosphorus compounds, and enhancing membrane transport capacity
Accumulating excess iron to substitute for phosphorus functions
questions.explanation: Plant responses to phosphorus deficiency are among the most elaborate nutrient stress adaptations: (1) Root morphological changes — (a) Increased root hair length and density: root hairs can increase 2-5 fold in length and number under Pi deficiency, dramatically expanding the soil volume explored. (b) Altered root architecture: primary root growth is inhibited while lateral root growth and branching increase, creating a more exploratory root system concentrated in the Pi-rich topsoil. (c) Cluster roots (proteoid roots): formed by species in families like Proteaceae, Lupinus (lupins), and Hakea. These are dense clusters of short lateral rootlets that release massive amounts of organic acids, creating localized acidification zones. (2) Chemical mobilization — (a) Organic acid secretion: citrate, malate, and oxalate are exuded from roots. These organic acids solubilize phosphorus that is bound to iron, aluminum, and calcium minerals by chelating the metal cations and releasing Pi. (b) Phosphatase secretion: acid phosphatases (APases) are secreted into the rhizosphere to hydrolyze organic phosphorus compounds (phytate, phospholipids, nucleotides), releasing inorganic Pi. Up to 30-80% of soil P can be in organic forms. (3) Transporter upregulation — PHT1 family high-affinity Pi transporters (Km = 1-10 μM) are strongly induced under Pi deficiency. Nine PHT1 members exist in Arabidopsis, with PHT1;1 and PHT1;4 being the major root Pi uptake transporters. (4) Internal reallocation — Pi is remobilized from older leaves (via phloem) to younger, growing tissues. Membrane phospholipids are replaced by sulfolipids and galactolipids (saving Pi). Intracellular Pi is released from vacuolar stores. (5) Mycorrhizal enhancement — Pi deficiency promotes mycorrhizal colonization and expression of mycorrhiza-specific Pi transporters (PHT1;6 in Medicago). Plants do not shut down root growth (A) or increase shoot:root ratio (B — the opposite happens). Iron accumulation (D) does not substitute for P functions.

questions.question:
Match the following types of xylem conduits with their characteristics:
(P) Vessel elements
(Q) Tracheids
(R) Protoxylem
(S) Metaxylem

1. First-formed xylem with annular or helical wall thickenings that permit stretching during organ elongation
2. Wide cells with perforation plates at end walls; found in angiosperms; connected end-to-end to form vessels
3. Elongated cells with tapered end walls lacking perforations; water passes through pit pairs; found in all vascular plants including gymnosperms
4. Later-formed xylem with reticulate or pitted wall thickenings; matures after organ elongation ceases
questions.explanation: Understanding the different types of xylem conducting elements is essential: (1) Vessel elements (P-2) — found predominantly in angiosperms (and a few other groups like Gnetales). Key feature: perforation plates at end walls — actual holes (complete removal of cell wall material) connecting adjacent vessel elements. This creates open tubes (vessels) that are highly efficient for water transport. Vessel elements are typically wider and shorter than tracheids. (2) Tracheids (Q-3) — the ancestral conducting element found in ALL vascular plants (ferns, gymnosperms, and angiosperms). Key feature: lack perforation plates. End walls are tapered and overlapping with adjacent tracheids. Water must pass through pit pairs (areas where the secondary wall is absent, leaving only the thin pit membrane/primary wall). This creates more resistance to flow than perforation plates. Tracheids serve both conduction and support functions. (3) Protoxylem (R-1) — the first xylem to differentiate in a developing organ. Matures while surrounding tissues are still elongating. Must have extensible wall thickenings: annular (ring-shaped) or helical (spiral) patterns allow the cell to be stretched as surrounding cells elongate without rupturing. Protoxylem vessels may eventually be torn apart and become non-functional as the organ continues to grow. (4) Metaxylem (S-4) — xylem that differentiates after organ elongation has slowed or stopped. Has more rigid wall thickenings: scalariform (ladder-like), reticulate (net-like), or pitted (nearly complete secondary wall). These patterns do not permit stretching but provide greater mechanical strength and water-conducting efficiency. Metaxylem vessels are typically wider than protoxylem and become the primary conducting elements in mature organs.

questions.question: Transpiration creates a water potential gradient from soil to leaves. In a tall tree (30 m), the gravitational component of water potential (Ψg) adds an additional energy cost for lifting water. The gravitational water potential is approximately:
options: -0.01 MPa per meter of height, contributing -0.3 MPa at 30 m — this gravitational component means that even in a fully hydrated tree with saturated soil, the water potential at the top of the xylem column would be about -0.3 MPa lower than at the base, solely due to gravity; transpirational pull must overcome this gravitational gradient in addition to frictional resistance along the xylem pathway
-1.0 MPa per meter of height, making trees over 10 m impossible
-10 MPa per meter, which is the dominant cost of water transport
Gravity has no effect on water potential in plants
questions.explanation: The gravitational component of water potential is important for understanding water transport in tall trees: (1) Gravitational water potential — Ψg = ρgh, where ρ = density of water (1000 kg/m3), g = gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s2), h = height. For each meter of height: Ψg = 1000 × 9.8 × 1 / 10^6 = 0.0098 MPa ≈ 0.01 MPa per meter. At 30 m height: Ψg = 0.01 × 30 = -0.3 MPa. (2) Complete water potential equation — for tall trees, the full equation is: Ψw = Ψs + Ψp + Ψg. The gravitational component is typically small compared to the other components and to the transpiration-driven tension, but it is not negligible in very tall trees. (3) Height limits — the tallest trees (coast redwoods, Sequoia sempervirens) reach about 115 m. At this height, Ψg ≈ -1.15 MPa. Combined with the xylem tension needed to overcome frictional resistance in the conducting pathway, and the tension needed to extract water from soil, the total xylem tension at the top can reach -2 to -3 MPa. Stomata at the top of very tall trees operate at more negative water potentials, reducing photosynthesis and potentially setting the ultimate height limit. (4) Theoretical maximum — Koch et al. (2004) estimated that the maximum tree height is approximately 122-130 m, based on the combined gravitational and frictional limits that would bring xylem tension to the cavitation threshold at the treetop. (5) Practical significance — while -0.3 MPa at 30 m seems small compared to typical leaf water potentials (-1 to -3 MPa), it represents a fixed baseline cost that must be overcome even under zero transpiration. Option B (-1 MPa/m) is 100x too large, C (-10 MPa/m) is 1000x too large, and D (no effect) ignores physics.

questions.question: Zinc (Zn) is an essential micronutrient for plants. Its most important biochemical role is:
options: Forming the central metal ion in the chlorophyll molecule

Acting as a structural and catalytic component of numerous enzymes and transcription factors — Zn2+ stabilizes protein structure in zinc finger domains (C2H2, RING, LIM types) of transcription factors and is a catalytic cofactor in enzymes including carbonic anhydrase, alcohol dehydrogenase, Cu/Zn superoxide dismutase, and RNA polymerase; Zn deficiency impairs auxin biosynthesis, reducing internode elongation and causing 'little leaf' symptoms
Serving as the primary electron carrier in the photosynthetic light reactions
Providing the red pigmentation in flower petals
questions.explanation: Zinc is second only to iron as the most abundant transition metal in plants: (1) Enzyme cofactor — Zn2+ is required by over 300 enzymes across all six enzyme classes. Key examples: (a) Carbonic anhydrase — converts CO2 + H2O ⇌ HCO3- + H+. Essential for CO2 supply to rubisco in C4 plants (in mesophyll cells) and for pH buffering. (b) Cu/Zn superoxide dismutase (SOD) — detoxifies superoxide radicals to H2O2. Critical for ROS defense. (c) Alcohol dehydrogenase — important for anaerobic metabolism during flooding. (d) RNA polymerases — require Zn2+ for catalytic activity. (2) Structural role — zinc finger domains are one of the most common protein structural motifs in eukaryotes. A Zn2+ ion coordinates with cysteine and/or histidine residues to stabilize a compact protein fold. Major types: (a) C2H2 zinc fingers — in many transcription factors regulating gene expression. (b) RING (Really Interesting New Gene) fingers — in E3 ubiquitin ligases. (c) LIM domains — in cytoskeletal organization. Over 2% of Arabidopsis proteins contain predicted zinc-binding domains. (3) Auxin connection — Zn is required for tryptophan biosynthesis (a precursor of the auxin IAA). Zn deficiency reduces tryptophan levels, impairs auxin production, and causes characteristic symptoms: reduced internode elongation (rosetting), small leaves ('little leaf'), and reduced apical dominance. (4) Required amount — Zn is needed at 20-100 ppm in plant tissue. Deficiency is common on alkaline, calcareous soils where Zn2+ solubility is very low. (5) Chlorophyll contains Mg, not Zn (A); electron carriers use Fe, Cu, and Mn, not Zn (C); and Zn does not provide pigmentation (D).

questions.question: Parasitic plants like Cuscuta (dodder) obtain water and nutrients from host plants through specialized penetrating organs called:
options: Mycorrhizae that form between the parasite and host roots

Haustoria — modified root-like organs that penetrate the host plant's tissues and form direct vascular connections with the host's xylem and phloem; haustoria allow the parasite to tap into the host's transpiration stream for water and minerals and into the host's phloem for photosynthetic sugars and amino acids
Tendrils that merely provide physical support without nutrient transfer
Adventitious roots that grow into the soil beneath the host plant
questions.explanation: Haustoria are the defining organ of parasitic plants: (1) Structure — haustoria are specialized organs that develop when a parasitic plant contacts a host stem or root. In Cuscuta (dodder, a stem parasite): the dodder seedling coils around a host stem, and haustorium primordia form at contact points. The haustorium penetrates the host's epidermis, cortex, and eventually reaches the vascular tissues. It forms searching hyphae-like cells that grow between and through host cells to make connections with host xylem and phloem. (2) Vascular connections — the mature haustorium establishes: (a) Xylem-to-xylem connections — parasite xylem elements directly abut or fuse with host xylem elements, allowing the parasite to tap into the host's transpiration stream. Water and dissolved minerals flow from host xylem into parasite xylem. (b) Phloem connections — parasite sieve tubes form connections with host phloem, often via specialized transfer cells at the interface. This allows the parasite to divert photosynthetic sugars and amino acids from the host's phloem. (3) Cuscuta specifics — Cuscuta is a holoparasite: it has no functional chlorophyll (or very little), no roots (except initial seedling root), and depends entirely on host xylem and phloem for water, minerals, and carbon. A single dodder plant can parasitize multiple hosts simultaneously. (4) Other parasitic plants — (a) Striga (witchweed) — root hemiparasite of grasses, major crop pest. (b) Orobanche (broomrape) — root holoparasite. (c) Rafflesia — produces world's largest flower, holoparasite on Tetrastigma vines. (d) Viscum/Phoradendron (mistletoe) — stem hemiparasite with chlorophyll, takes mainly water/minerals. (5) Mycorrhizae (A) are mutualistic fungal associations, not parasitic organs. Tendrils (C) provide support but no vascular connections. Soil roots (D) would make the plant autotrophic, not parasitic.

questions.question: A plant physiologist uses fluorescent dye (carboxyfluorescein, CF) applied to a source leaf to visualize phloem transport. After 30 minutes, the dye appears in developing fruits above the labeled leaf and in root tips below, but NOT in mature stem internodes between the source leaf and sink tissues. This observation indicates that:
options: Phloem sap does not actually flow through the stem
CF was degraded in the stem and regenerated at the sinks

Phloem sap moves through the stem as bulk flow without significant lateral unloading in mature, non-growing internodes — the dye passes through the stem phloem quickly as part of the mass flow stream but does not exit the sieve tubes in regions that are not active sinks; CF only accumulates visibly at true sink destinations where phloem unloading occurs, demonstrating source-to-sink specificity of transport
The dye was transported by xylem, not phloem
questions.explanation: This fluorescent tracer experiment demonstrates important properties of phloem transport: (1) CF as phloem tracer — carboxyfluorescein (CF, or its membrane-permeant precursor CFDA/carboxyfluorescein diacetate) is loaded into phloem when applied to source tissues. Being phloem-mobile and fluorescent, it can be tracked by fluorescence microscopy. CF is a good proxy for phloem sap movement because it travels with the mass flow stream. (2) Observation explained — CF appearing at sinks (fruits, root tips) but not accumulating in mature stem confirms: (a) The phloem transport pathway through the stem is intact and functioning (sap clearly passes through). (b) But CF (and by extension, phloem sap) does not significantly leave the sieve tubes in mature, non-growing stem internodes. (c) CF accumulates only where phloem unloading is active — at sink tissues with metabolic demand for imported sugars. (3) Source-to-sink transport — this demonstrates that phloem is a directed transport system: sap flows from source to sink without leaking out along the way. The sieve tubes in mature stem internodes are essentially a sealed pipeline — their sieve plate pores are open for longitudinal flow, but lateral unloading into surrounding tissues is minimal because mature stem cells have low metabolic demand and are not active sinks. (4) Unloading specificity — phloem unloading occurs specifically at sink tissues through: (a) symplastic unloading via plasmodesmata (in root tips, shoot apices), (b) apoplastic unloading via sucrose efflux carriers and subsequent invertase-mediated hydrolysis (in fruits, seeds). (5) Phloem sap clearly flows through the stem (A is wrong), CF is stable (B is wrong), and CF/CFDA is specifically loaded into phloem (not xylem — D is wrong).

questions.question: Silicon (Si) is considered a 'beneficial element' rather than an essential mineral nutrient for most plants. In grasses and some other species, silicon deposition provides:
options: Enhanced mechanical strength and resistance to lodging, pathogen attack, and insect herbivory — silicon is deposited as amorphous silica (SiO2·nH2O, called phytoliths) in cell walls and on leaf surfaces; silicified leaf surfaces are abrasive to insect mandibles, and silica deposition strengthens stems against bending (lodging) and creates physical barriers against fungal penetration
A replacement for phosphorus in ATP synthesis
The primary pigment responsible for green coloration in grass leaves
Active transport of sugars from root to shoot via silicon channels
questions.explanation: Silicon is the second most abundant element in the Earth's crust and plays important roles in many plant species: (1) Uptake and transport — silicon is absorbed by roots as silicic acid (Si(OH)4) through specific silicon influx (Lsi1/NIP2;1, an aquaporin-type channel) and efflux (Lsi2, an active transporter) transporters. It is transported in the xylem as silicic acid and deposited as amorphous silica (SiO2·nH2O) at sites of transpiration (leaf epidermis, trichomes). (2) Mechanical strengthening — silica deposits in cell walls and on epidermal surfaces dramatically increase tissue rigidity. In rice and other cereals, silicon makes up 5-10% of dry weight in leaves and stems. Silicified stems resist lodging (falling over) in wind and rain, which is critical for grain crops. Silicon-deficient rice lodges severely, reducing yield. (3) Pest resistance — (a) Insect defense: silica particles on leaf surfaces and in trichomes are extremely hard (Mohs hardness 7) and wear down insect mandibles, reducing feeding. Silicified trichomes physically deter small insects. (b) Fungal resistance: silica deposited beneath the cuticle and in cell walls creates physical barriers to fungal hyphae penetration. Silicon application reduces severity of blast disease (Magnaporthe) in rice, powdery mildew in wheat, and many other fungal diseases. (4) Phytoliths — silica bodies (phytoliths) persist in soil after plant decomposition and can be used for paleobotanical and archaeological studies (identifying ancient plant communities and agricultural practices). (5) 'Beneficial' vs. 'essential' — silicon meets essentiality criteria for some species (rice, horsetails) but not for model plants like Arabidopsis. It is classified as 'beneficial' for most plants: not strictly essential for completing the life cycle but significantly improving growth, yield, and stress tolerance. Silicon does not replace P (B), is not a pigment (C), and does not transport sugars (D).

questions.question: In the xylem, the movement of water from one tracheid to an adjacent tracheid occurs primarily through:
options: Pit pairs — areas where the secondary wall is absent on both adjacent cells, leaving only the thin pit membrane (consisting of the primary walls and middle lamella of both cells); water passes through the porous pit membrane from one tracheid lumen to the next, with the pit membrane pores providing the resistance to flow and also serving as safety valves against embolism spread
Open perforation plates at the tracheid end walls
Plasmodesmata connecting the protoplasts of adjacent tracheids
Transpiration-independent active pumping by tracheid wall proteins
questions.explanation: Pit pairs are the defining water transport pathway between tracheids: (1) Tracheid vs. vessel element — the fundamental difference: tracheids lack perforation plates (B is wrong — perforations are found only in vessel elements). Water moving from one tracheid to the next must pass through pit pairs, where it crosses the thin pit membrane. This creates more resistance to flow compared to the open perforations in vessel elements, which is why tracheid-based xylem (gymnosperms) is generally less efficient than vessel-based xylem (angiosperms).
