questions.question: A researcher grafts the shoot of a late-flowering Arabidopsis ecotype onto the rootstock of an early-flowering ecotype and vice versa. The early-flowering shoots flower early regardless of rootstock genotype, while the late-flowering shoots flower late regardless of rootstock genotype. However, when a single leaf from the early-flowering plant is grafted onto the late-flowering plant under inductive photoperiod, the late-flowering plant flowers early. What do these results demonstrate?
options: Flowering is controlled exclusively by the root system through cytokinin signals
The graft junction blocks all molecular communication between stock and scion

A leaf-derived mobile signal (florigen/FT protein) produced under inductive photoperiod can move through the phloem across a graft junction to induce flowering at the distant shoot apex — the signal originates in leaves (not roots), requires inductive photoperiod for production, and acts at the shoot apical meristem to trigger the floral transition
Flowering time is determined solely by the age of the plant, not by any mobile signal
questions.explanation: This classic grafting experiment demonstrates the existence and properties of florigen: (1) First grafting result — early shoot on late root still flowers early, and late shoot on early root still flowers late. This shows that the shoot (or more specifically, the leaves) determines flowering time, not the roots. The rootstock genotype is irrelevant. (2) Leaf grafting result — a single leaf from the early-flowering plant, when grafted onto the late-flowering plant, induces early flowering. This proves: (a) The flowering signal originates in leaves. (b) The signal is mobile — it can move from the grafted leaf through the vascular system (phloem) to the shoot apex. (c) The signal can cross a graft junction (demonstrating it is a small molecule or protein, not a physical structure). (d) A single leaf is sufficient to produce enough signal. (3) Molecular identity — the mobile signal is now known to be FT (FLOWERING LOCUS T) protein, produced in leaf companion cells and transported through the phloem. The protein (not the mRNA) is the mobile form. (4) Historical context — Chailakhyan (1936) first proposed florigen based on similar grafting experiments. Zeevaart and others refined the concept. The molecular identity was established by Corbesier et al. (2007) using phloem-sap proteomics and tissue-specific expression experiments. (5) Not root-derived (A — the first experiment rules this out). The graft junction is clearly permeable to the signal (B is wrong). Age alone doesn't explain the leaf graft result (D is wrong — the signal requires photoperiod).

questions.question: The soil cation exchange capacity (CEC) is an important property affecting plant mineral nutrition. CEC refers to:
options: The ability of soil to convert atmospheric N2 to NH4+
The rate at which soil bacteria decompose organic matter

The total amount of exchangeable cations (K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, NH4+, Na+, H+, Al3+) that soil particles can adsorb on their negatively charged surfaces — clay particles and humus have permanent and pH-dependent negative charges that electrostatically attract cations; higher CEC soils retain more nutrient cations against leaching and release them to the soil solution for root uptake through ion exchange
The capacity of soil to store water between field capacity and wilting point
questions.explanation: CEC is fundamental to understanding soil fertility and nutrient availability: (1) Soil negative charges — soil particles carry negative surface charges from two sources: (a) Permanent charges — in clay minerals (montmorillonite, vermiculite), isomorphic substitution (replacement of Si4+ by Al3+ in tetrahedral layers, or Al3+ by Mg2+ in octahedral layers) creates permanent negative charges on the mineral surface. (b) pH-dependent charges — carboxyl (-COOH) and phenolic (-OH) groups on humus, and broken edges of clay minerals, acquire negative charges at higher pH (deprotonation). (2) Cation exchange — these negative charges attract and loosely bind cations (K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, NH4+, Na+, H+, Al3+) from the soil solution through electrostatic attraction. Bound cations are in dynamic equilibrium with the soil solution — they can be displaced ('exchanged') by other cations, including H+ released by root cells. (3) CEC values — expressed in cmolc/kg (centimoles of charge per kilogram of soil) or meq/100g. Typical values: sandy soils 1-5 cmolc/kg (low CEC, poor nutrient retention); loamy soils 10-25 cmolc/kg; clay soils 25-100 cmolc/kg; organic/peat soils 100-300+ cmolc/kg. (4) Nutritional significance — high CEC soils: (a) Retain more nutrient cations, reducing leaching losses. (b) Buffer soil pH changes more effectively. (c) Release nutrients to the soil solution as roots deplete it. Low CEC soils (sandy) lose nutrients rapidly through leaching, requiring more frequent fertilizer application. (5) CEC is not nitrogen fixation (A), organic matter decomposition (B), or water storage capacity (D — that is 'available water capacity').

questions.question: P-proteins (phloem proteins) are structural proteins found in sieve tube elements. Their most important function is:
options: Providing structural support to sieve plates like the cytoskeleton in animal cells

Wound sealing — when a sieve tube is damaged, P-proteins rapidly aggregate at the sieve plate pores, forming a proteinaceous plug that blocks the sieve plate and prevents loss of phloem sap under pressure; this rapid wound response (occurring within seconds) is analogous to blood clotting in animals and protects the plant from catastrophic loss of photosynthetic products
Catalyzing the synthesis of sucrose from glucose and fructose
Actively pumping phloem sap through sieve plate pores
questions.explanation: P-proteins are specialized structural proteins unique to angiosperm sieve tube elements: (1) Types of P-proteins — several forms exist: (a) P-protein filaments (PP1, PP2 in Cucurbita) — the most studied. PP1 is a structural protein that forms filaments; PP2 is a lectin with phloem-specific expression. (b) P-protein bodies — crystalline inclusions in developing sieve tube elements that disperse into filaments at maturity. (c) Forisomes — unique to Fabaceae (legumes), these are specialized P-protein bodies that undergo rapid, reversible conformational changes (contraction/expansion) in response to Ca2+ and are involved in sieve plate sealing. (2) Wound sealing — the primary function of P-proteins is rapid wound response: (a) When a sieve tube is severed (e.g., by insect feeding, herbivore damage, or experimental cutting), the positive turgor pressure causes rapid sap exudation. (b) P-proteins in the sap are swept toward the sieve plate by the surge of sap flow. (c) Within seconds, P-proteins accumulate at sieve plate pores, forming a proteinaceous plug that blocks further sap loss. (d) Callose is then deposited (over minutes to hours) to provide a more permanent seal. (3) Fabaceae forisomes — in legumes, forisomes are spindle-shaped protein bodies that undergo Ca2+-dependent expansion when damage causes Ca2+ to spike. The expanded forisome physically blocks the sieve tube lumen, stopping sap flow almost instantaneously. (4) Not structural support (A — sieve tubes lack cytoskeleton). Not sucrose synthesis (C — sucrose synthase is a different enzyme). Not active pumping (D — phloem transport is pressure-driven, not protein-pumped).
